description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 16The Estonian government denied claims Tallinn is about to be locked down, or a curfew imposed, which have spread on social media with people claiming to have seen roadblocks being built on the outskirts of Tallinn. The city government is actually installing temporary traffic lights and renovating an intersection.

description: In the Estonian capital, Tallinn, Tallinn Kristiine High School (Tallinna Kristiine Gümnaasium) was closed for a period of two weeks starting from March 6, 2020, due to a student being diagnosed with COVID-19 coronavirus. As a precautionary measure, all 850 students have been instructed to stay at home during this time. They will receive their coursework online to continue their studies remotely. Additionally, students are requested not to participate in any group activities, including sports and hobby pursuits, until the school reopens.

type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)

description: Estonia, March 13, 2020. By the order of Prime Minister of Estonia, the local authorities are required to develop and suggest solutions as soon as possible for ensuring the well-being of preschool-age children in cases where their parents need to be at work. These proposals should be promptly presented to the individual responsible for managing emergency situations.

description: As of 9 April 2020, Estonia mandates that schools and activities held in schools must go online and suspend regular learning. UPDATE: As of 15-May 2020, in Estonia return to the usual education activities in school premises is allowed and special conditions are: groups of up to 10 members; commonly used items in school rooms must be disinfected often, and rooms must be aired. Wearing a protective mask is not mandatory. At the same time, wearing a mask as well as using other personal protective equipment is strongly recommended for informal education providers, teachers, academic staff, pupils, and students who belong to a risk group.

description: It was announced on May 17, 2020, that the Estonia Government approved easing of restrictions in force after the end of the emergency situation. Starting from May 19, 2020, Education in lower secondary schools, upper secondary schools, vocational education institutions and higher education institutions (except in research and development institutions of universities and research institutions), as well as in continuous education institutions, informal education, and hobby activities, and the activities of open youth centers must follow the 2+2 rule; students may work in groups of no more than 10 students (except for exams); when organising the exams the students must be dispersed in the exam room, the movement of groups of students must be dispersed, and all items in common use must be disinfected after use.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with conditions

description:
July 1, 2020. Estonia Government allows all basic schools, upper secondary schools, vocational educational institutions and institutions of higher education, to organise indoor public events if the following requirements are met:  
1) The organiser of an event ensures the scattering of people
2) The organiser of an indoor event ensures up to 50% attendance capacity but no more than 1500 people
 UPDATE: 11.09.2020 "High school students in Tallinn will start part-time distance learning next week."

description: September 9, 2020. Tallinn city government orders kindergartens to receive and hand over children outdoors. Kindergarten staff who receive children and interact with parents will use a visor and personal protective equipment. Direct contact between groups is to be avoided.

description: September 9, 2020. Tallinn city government reacts to the increasing rate of coronavirus infection in the capital. Thermal cameras will be installed in all schools during September. Children with signs of illness will be identified in schools and sent home if necessary. To reduce contacts, schools will implement flexible learning arrangements, such as entering from separate doors, a staggered start to the day, different breaks, including meal breaks, and outdoor learning opportunities. Teachers must use visors.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Other Health Monitoring,Special provisions exist for how teaching is done which applies to all teachers,Special provisions for all students in a school (e.g. students in primary school do not have to social distance)

description: Starting from 11 March 2021, in Estonia students in grades 1 to 4 are not allowed to be in the school buildings anymore either, and those preparing for the basic school final exams and state exams will not be allowed to have contact learning. It is still foreseen that in emergency cases, primary school students may continue to spend time in school buildings and participate in activities organised there. Children with special educational needs and institutions managing them can remain open in a limited and safe capacity.

description: Starting from 11 March 2021, in Estonia students in grades 1 to 4 are not allowed to be in the school buildings anymore either, and those preparing for the basic school final exams and state exams will not be allowed to have contact learning. It is still foreseen that in emergency cases, primary school students may continue to spend time in school buildings and participate in activities organised there. Children with special educational needs and institutions managing them can remain open in a limited and safe capacity. UPDATE: From 17 May 2021, in Estonia contact learning will be allowed for all students of general education schools, vocational schools, universities of applied sciences, and higher education institutions. The general health protection requirements and the instructions and recommendations of the Ministry of Education and Research must be taken into account when organising studies. Indoors, care must be taken to ensure air quality through ventilation.

description:
On April 2 2020, the Estonian government approved the amendments to the Aliens Act and the Obligation to Leave and Prohibition on Entry Act with the aim of ensuring that foreigners from third countries who have lost their jobs leave Estonia at the earliest possibility. In such cases, the Police and Border Guard Board can annul a foreigner's visa or visa-free period and issue a precept ordering them to leave Estonia. 

In case a foreigner's visa or visa-free period expires but they are temporarily unable to leave Estonia due to the movement restrictions imposed under the emergency situation, according to the draft, the Minister of the Interior or the Director General of the Police and Border Guard Board can grant them grounds for remaining in Estonia until the end of the emergency situation.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Visa restrictions (e.g. suspend issuance of visa)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: 21st April 2020, an amendment to the Aliens Act has passed through the Riigikogu and has been entered into law by the Estonian Parliament.  The amendment requires non-EU foreigners with expired short-term work permits to depart Estonia as soon as possible.  This amendment does not impact individuals holding temporary residence permits.  If current emergency border closures prevent departure, impacted individuals may temporarily remain in Estonia but must depart within 10 days of the emergency situation being lifted.  Agricultural workers on short-term work permits will be granted the option of extending their work permit until July 31st, 2020.

description: From 1st June 2020, Estonia lifts entry restrictions for persons with no symptoms of disease coming from EU member states, the Schengen area, or the United Kingdom if they have stayed in one of the mentioned countries where in the past 14 days the coronavirus infection rate has been no more than 25 cases per 100,000 inhabitants. If a person arrives from a listed country where the infection rate is higher than 15 cases per 100,000 inhabitants during the past 14 days, they must remain in quarantine for 14 days.

description:
Estonian government is to set up full border controls. From 17 March 2020 onward only the following people allowed to enter the country: citizens of Estonia, permanent residents, their relatives, and transport workers carrying out freight transport. 
 UPDATE: Originally, full border restrictions were set up between Estonia and all other countries on 17th March 2020. From 1 June 2020, Estonia will open its borders to the European Union, Schengen and the United Kingdom, while keeping its borders closed to the rest of the world.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
From 1st June 2020, Estonia lifts entry restrictions for persons with no symptoms of disease coming from EU member states, the Schengen area, or the United Kingdom if they have stayed in one of the mentioned countries where in the past 14 days the coronavirus infection rate has been no more than 25 cases per 100,000 inhabitants. If a person arrives from a listed country where the infection rate is higher than 15 cases per 100,000 inhabitants during the past 14 days, they must remain in quarantine for 14 days. UPDATE: The original policy states that Estonia keeps its borders closed for all countries outside the European Union, Schengen and the United Kingdom, The government is now, 6th July, 2020, opening the borders to "low-infection" countries outside the European Union, which was recommended by the Council of the European Union. Further, the list of third countries from which entry into Estonia is permitted will be updated every two weeks and published on the website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Additionally, from 6th July 2020, all travellers without symptoms with the purpose of coming to work or study in Estonia are allowed to enter the country, although condition of mandatory self-isolation might apply.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (without the UK),Schengen Area (without the UK)

In addition, people who are symptom-free and possess either Latvian or Lithuanian citizenship, a residence permit, or a right of residence in Latvia or Lithuania, or have their primary residence registered in Latvia or Lithuania, are permitted to cross the state border to enter Estonia. UPDATE: The policy was in effect until May 31, 2020. It was extended until June 11, 2020.

description:
As of 23rd June 2020, travel to Estonia still remains restricted for travelers outside of the EU and Schengen countries UK. UPDATE: "From 6th of July 2020, Estonia is opening its borders to low-infection countries outside the European Union, based on the recommendation given by the Council of the European Union. The list of these countries will be updated every two weeks. This means that the borders remain closed for travellers from countries not included in this list or countries not members of the European Union, Schengen or the United Kingdom.

Additionally, the borders will open to travellers from all countries who are coming to Estonia with the purpose of work or study. However, these travellers may be subject to self-isolation."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From 15th April 2020, Estonia requires stringent border security and checks at the Esti-Latvian border and at seaports. UPDATE: The policy was repealed on June 30, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 1st July 2020, the Estonian government advises against travel abroad. Traveling for tourism is not safe and is discouraged. If the trip is urgent, consider the following  Before going abroad get to know the conditions for entering the country of destination  find out whether you will be allowed into the country. If in doubt, contact the Border Guard of the destination country. If you have to go through any other countries to reach your destination, find out the transit rules of those countries as well. It is not possible to use the special flights that are bringing Estonian residents home for travelling abroad. Take into account that in order to limit the spread of the corona virus, the states can unexpectedly restrict the conditions for entering their country and moving around there. You can get stuck in quarantine abroad and getting home could be very complicated, sometimes impossible.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
From 6th of July 2020, Estonia is opening its borders to low-infection countries outside the European Union, based on the recommendation given by the Council of the European Union. The list of these countries will be updated every two weeks. This means that the borders remain closed for travellers from countries not included in this list or countries not members of the European Union, Schengen or the United Kingdom.

Additionally, the borders will open to travellers from all countries who are coming to Estonia with the purpose of work or study. However, these travellers may be subject to self-isolation.

description: Estonia. July 6, 2020. Following the temporary measures that have been introduced to restrict the crossing of state borders with the aim of preventing a potential new outbreak of COVID-19, asymptomatic citizens, residents, and long-stay visa holders from the European Union, European Economic Area, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, and the Vatican City State, along with their asymptomatic family members, are now permitted to cross the state border to enter Estonia as well.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (without the UK),Other Regions (please specify below)

description:
From 1st June 2020, Estonia is opening its borders for travellers from European Union and Schengen countries as well as from the United Kingdom. This means that Estonia is now reopening its borders for the European free-movement area after closing its borders on the 17th of March 2020. Estonian borders remain closed for countries outside the regional block. UPDATE: The original policy states that Estonia keeps its borders closed for all countries outside the European Union, Schengen and the United Kingdom, The government is now, 6th July, 2020, opening the borders to "low-infection" countries outside the European Union, which was recommended by the Council of the European Union. Further, the list of third countries from which entry into Estonia is permitted will be updated every two weeks and published on the website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Additionally, from 6th July 2020, all travellers without symptoms with the purpose of coming to work or study in Estonia are allowed to enter the country, although condition of mandatory self-isolation might apply.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 21st May 2020, Estonia levies restrictions on border traffic and travel. Crossing is only allowed for those with Estonian citizenship, an Estonian residence permit. Asymptomatic forreign passengers who are traveling for key working (for details see the clauses 2-9) may also cross the border if necessary. In addition, people who are symptom-free and possess either Latvian or Lithuanian citizenship, a residence permit, or a right of residence in Latvia or Lithuania, or have their primary residence registered in Latvia or Lithuania, are permitted to cross the state border to enter Estonia. UPDATE: The policy was in effect until July 5, 2020. It was extended until August 27, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description: Estonia has launched a new Digital Nomad Visa  on 1st august 2020, that allows remote workers to live in Estonia and legally work for their employer or their own company registered abroad. The following may apply  persons who are able to work remotely; persons can perform their work duties remotely using telecommunications technology; persons who either have an active employment contract with a company registered outside of Estonia, conduct business thorugh their own company registered abroad, or work as a freelancer for clients mostly outside of Estonia; and, they can provide evidence that their income met the minimum threshold during the six months preceding the application. Currently, the monthly income threshold is    3504  gross of tax . This is currently only open to countries which the EU deems safe for interregional travel.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On 28 August 2020, Estonian government members approved a conceptual decision to continue with the current air travel restrictions for countries where the COVID-19 infection rate has been 25 or higher per 100,000 people in the last 14 days. Exceptions for these include Frankfurt, Helsinki, Copenhagen, London, Riga, and Warsaw. These cities are open for travelling from the Tallinn Airport regardless of the prevalence rates. Acceptable destinations are also countries where the prevalence rate per 100,000 people remains under 25 people.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Frankfurt, Helsinki, Copenhagen, London, Riga and Warsaw

Asymptomatic forreign passengers who are traveling for key working (for details see the clauses 2-9) may also cross the border if necessary. In addition, people who are symptom-free and possess either Latvian or Lithuanian citizenship, a residence permit, or a right of residence in Latvia or Lithuania, or have their primary residence registered in Latvia or Lithuania, are permitted to cross the state border to enter Estonia. UPDATE: The policy was in effect until August 27, 2020. It was extended until September 13, 2020.

description: From, 1st September 2020, in the event of a negative COVID-19 test result, it will be possible to go to work after coming from countries at risk if this is absolutely necessary and a negative virus test is given immediately upon arrival in the country. A second test must be performed no earlier than 7 days after the result of the first test, and if it is negative, normal life can be resumed. This means that a person will not be subjected to 14-day self-isolation after two negative tests, which applies to all those coming from high-risk countries who do not take the test.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
From, 1st September 2020, in the event of a negative COVID-19 test result, it will be possible to go to work after coming from countries at risk if this is absolutely necessary and a negative virus test is given immediately upon arrival in the country. A second test must be performed no earlier than 7 days after the result of the first test, and if it is negative, normal life can be resumed. This means that a person will not be subjected to 14-day self-isolation after two negative tests, which applies to all those coming from high-risk countries who do not take the test. UPDATE: "From 15th January 2021, The government has established a pre-entry and post-entry testing procedure for entering Estonia from a country with a high risk of coronavirus infection, coming into force on the 15th of January.   Those who want to avoid self-isolation must take a PCR test up to 72 hours before arrival in Estonia. While staying in Estonia, it is then possible to take a second test from the 6th day after the first test taken abroad.
"
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On May 17, 2020, Minister of Economic Affairs and Infrastructure, Taavi Aas, signed an order prohibiting flights from Estonia to countries with a high risk of being infected with COVID-19. The listed countries included the United Kingdom, Sweden, Belgium, Denmark, Turkey, Belarus, and Russia, and the ban on flights with them was effective from May 18, 2020. UPDATE: From, 1st September 2020, in the event of a negative COVID-19 test result, it will be possible to go to work after coming from countries at risk if this is absolutely necessary and a negative virus test is given immediately upon arrival in the country. A second test must be performed no earlier than 7 days after the result of the first test, and if it is negative, normal life can be resumed. This means that a person will not be subjected to 14-day self-isolation after two negative tests, which applies to all those coming from high-risk countries who do not take the test.

description:
From 14th September 2020, , the following are considered risk countries by Estonia as they have an infection rate of 16 cases per 100,000 people or higher  Andorra, Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Luxebmouarg, Malta, Monaco, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, San Marino, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. UPDATE: "from March 7th 2021, Authorities in Estonia have restricted the freedom of movement for ten days, for citizens of 26 countries, in which the Coronavirus infection rate is higher than 150 people per 100,000 inhabitants in the past 14 days, Estonia’s recent preventive measure will affect the following countries Austria,  Andorra, Belgium, Bulgaria, Cyprus, the Netherlands, Spain, Italy,  Ireland, Greece, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Latvia, Monaco, Portugal, Poland,  France, Romania, Sweden, San Marino, Slovakia, Switzerland, Slovenia, the Czech Republic as well as Hungary.

Citizens of Norway, Croatia, Liechtenstein, Iceland, Finland, Germany, and Denmark will be excluded from the restrictions as they have a lower rate of COVID-19 infection cases compared to other countries, in the past two weeks"

description: from 14th September 2020, Estonia maintains restrictions on the freedom of movement, including a 14 quarantine for those arriving in Estonia. UPDATE: From 12 November 2020, Exceptions for entry restrictions to Estonia  People are allowed to enter Estonia and do not have to follow the restrictions on the freedom of movement if they have no symptoms of the disease and they had the same rights before.  For example, freight and raw materials transporters, people involved in international cargo and passenger transport, people involved in the technical work of a company operating in Estonia, health care providers, diplomats, people arriving within the framework of international military cooperation, and people with special permits to enter. The citizens of Latvia and Lithuania, the holder of a residence permit or right of residence of these countries, can also enter Estonia and do not have to stay at home if they display no symptoms of the disease. Finnish citizens, holders of residence permits or people with rights of residence in Finland, who come to Estonia to work, study or visit for family reasons, such as meeting with a close relative, funeral, weddings, case of illness, are allowed to enter Estonia.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From 21st May 2020, Estonia levies restrictions on border traffic and travel. Crossing is only allowed for those with Estonian citizenship, an Estonian residence permit. Asymptomatic forreign passengers who are traveling for key working (for details see the clauses 2-9) may also cross the border if necessary. In addition, people who are symptom-free and possess either Latvian or Lithuanian citizenship, a residence permit, or a right of residence in Latvia or Lithuania, or have their primary residence registered in Latvia or Lithuania, are permitted to cross the state border to enter Estonia. UPDATE: The policy was in effect until September 12, 2020. It was extended until February 18, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description: The Estonian government decided to relax its regulations concerning restrictions on direct passenger air travel between Estonia and other European Countries. From 5th October 2020, direct passenger connections with Estonia are allowed if the country's infection rate is lower than the European average per 100 000 inhabitants in the last 14 days. The list of these countries is updated every Friday.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 28 August 2020, Estonian government members approved a conceptual decision to continue with the current air travel restrictions for countries where the COVID-19 infection rate has been 25 or higher per 100,000 people in the last 14 days. Exceptions for these include Frankfurt, Helsinki, Copenhagen, London, Riga, and Warsaw. These cities are open for travelling from the Tallinn Airport regardless of the prevalence rates. Acceptable destinations are also countries where the prevalence rate per 100,000 people remains under 25 people. UPDATE: The Estonian government decided to relax its regulations concerning restrictions on direct passenger air travel between Estonia and other European Countries. From 5th October 2020, direct passenger connections with Estonia are allowed if the country's infection rate is lower than the European average per 100 000 inhabitants in the last 14 days. The list of these countries is updated every Friday.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Frankfurt, Helsinki, Copenhagen, London, Riga and Warsaw

Until the test result is known, a person must remain in self-isolation

description: From 15th January 2021, The government has established a pre-entry and post-entry testing procedure for entering Estonia from a country with a high risk of coronavirus infection, coming into force on the 15th of January. While staying in Estonia, it is then possible to take a second test from the 6th day after the first test taken abroad.

description: On 2nd February 2021, the Government approved Estonia’s positions on the EU Council’s recommendations concerning a coordinated approach to the temporary restriction of non-essential travel in order to prevent the continued spread of COVID-19.    The EU Council’s proposals aim to limit non-essential movement both within the EU and from third countries, due to the spread of COVID-19. These include, for example, testing requirements before travelling and upon arrival, as well as self-isolation requirements.

description: On 2nd February 2021, the Government approved Estonia’s positions on the EU Council’s recommendations concerning a coordinated approach to the temporary restriction of non-essential travel in order to prevent the continued spread of COVID-19.    The EU Council’s proposals aim to limit non-essential movement both within the EU and from third countries, due to the spread of COVID-19. These include, for example, testing requirements before travelling and upon arrival, as well as self-isolation requirements. UPDATE: from 8th March 2021, Estonian citizens and residents are allowed into the country regardless of whether they are symptomatic or not. Citizens and residents of the Schengen area are allowed to enter the country if they are not symptomatic.     Entering Estonia from outside the European Union, European Economic Area or Schengen area, for tourism, among other things, is only allowed from countries listed in Annex 1 of the recommendation enacted by the Council of the European Union. The movement restriction applies if the infection indicator of a country listed in Annex 1 is higher than 16.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From 21st May 2020, Estonia levies restrictions on border traffic and travel. Crossing is only allowed for those with Estonian citizenship, an Estonian residence permit. Asymptomatic forreign passengers who are traveling for key working (for details see the clauses 2-9) may also cross the border if necessary. In addition, people who are symptom-free and possess either Latvian or Lithuanian citizenship, a residence permit, or a right of residence in Latvia or Lithuania, or have their primary residence registered in Latvia or Lithuania, are permitted to cross the state border to enter Estonia. UPDATE: The policy was in effect until February 18, 2021. It was extended until June 20, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From 1st March 2021, there is an Updated list of countries eligible to enter from March 1-7. Estonia has updated its list of countries, the citizens of which will be eligible to enter its territory from March 1 until March 7 with restrictions, after taking into account the Coronavirus situation in other states.The updated statement clarifies that the following countries, which according to Estonias government, have an infection rate higher than 150 people per 100,000 inhabitants during the past two weeks, will be subject to a 10-day restriction on freedom of movement from March 1 until March 7: Andorra, Austria, Belgium,Bulgaria, Spain, the Netherlands, Ireland,Italy,Cyprus, Lithuania,Luxembourg,Latvia,Malta,Monaco, Poland,Portugal,France,Sweden,Romania,Slovakia, San Marino, Slovenia, the Czech Republic, Switzerland.

description:
from March 7th 2021, Authorities in Estonia have restricted the freedom of movement for ten days, for citizens of 26 countries, in which the Coronavirus infection rate is higher than 150 people per 100,000 inhabitants in the past 14 days, Estonia’s recent preventive measure will affect the following countries Austria,  Andorra, Belgium, Bulgaria, Cyprus, the Netherlands, Spain, Italy,  Ireland, Greece, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Latvia, Monaco, Portugal, Poland,  France, Romania, Sweden, San Marino, Slovakia, Switzerland, Slovenia, the Czech Republic as well as Hungary.

Citizens of Norway, Croatia, Liechtenstein, Iceland, Finland, Germany, and Denmark will be excluded from the restrictions as they have a lower rate of COVID-19 infection cases compared to other countries, in the past two weeks
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From 14th August 2020, travel to Estonia is possible for the following  citizens and residents of the EU, Schengen area, the United Kingdom, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, Vatican City, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay and individuals with long-stay visas and their family members if they show no symptoms. Citizens of Norway, Croatia, Liechtenstein, Iceland, Finland, Germany, and Denmark will be excluded from the restrictions as they have a lower rate of COVID-19 infection cases compared to other countries, in the past two weeks"

description:
From 19th October 2020, Estonia wishes to restore the common movement zone between the Baltic states and Finland, since the COVID-19-related epidemiological situation is similar in the region, and a common movement zone creates an opportunity to keep life as normal as possible in the region.The recommendation to only travel in the case of unavoidable need is still in effect; this is especially topical considering the upcoming school holiday.When travelling from Estonia to Latvia, Lithuania or Finland, and returning to Estonia, a person may take the coronavirus test in the home country as well, and in the event of a negative result, they may return to their normal life. Until the test result is known, a person must remain in self-isolation UPDATE: "From March 7th 2021, Authorities in Estonia have restricted the freedom of movement for ten days, for citizens of 26 countries, in which the Coronavirus infection rate is higher than 150 people per 100,000 inhabitants in the past 14 days, Estonia’s recent preventive measure will affect the following countries Austria,  Andorra, Belgium, Bulgaria, Cyprus, the Netherlands, Spain, Italy,  Ireland, Greece, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Latvia, Monaco, Portugal, Poland,  France, Romania, Sweden, San Marino, Slovakia, Switzerland, Slovenia, the Czech Republic as well as Hungary.

Citizens of Norway, Croatia, Liechtenstein, Iceland, Finland, Germany, and Denmark will be excluded from the restrictions as they have a lower rate of COVID-19 infection cases compared to other countries, in the past two weeks"

description: before arriving in estonia, you must fill out a traveller's questionnaire. the questionnaire can be completed within three days of your arrival in estonia. this makes border-crossing smoother and you can avoid queueing for filling out the questionnaire on paper. the border guard or airline can ask people crossing the border to present an electronic or printed border crossing confirmation sent via email. those individuals who have already had covid-19 or who have been vaccinated, or any other individuals who are not subject to restrictions on their freedom of movement pursuant to the respective order by the government of the republic of estonia are not required to submit the declaration if they are able to provide proof of the grounds for their exemption.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
From 3 May 2021, commuting across the Estonian border with Latvia is allowed provided the individual displays a negative COVID-19 test within the past 7 days prior to travel. The regulation requires that the individual crosses the Estonian-Latvian border at least twice per week, for the purpose of work or study. UPDATE: From 20.09.2021 Asymptomatic citizens from other countries can also come to Estonia to study, work or for purposes of tourism, sports, culture, etc
A person is not subject to a movement restriction if he arrives into Estonia from a European Union, European Economic Area or Schengen area country where the infection indicator is less than 150 people per 100 000 residents within the past 14 days. If the indicator is higher, the person must adhere to the 10-day movement restriction.
Entering Estonia from outside the European Union, European Economic Area or Schengen area, for tourism, among other things, is allowed from countries listed in Annex 1 of the recommendation enacted by the Council of the European Union. The movement restriction applies if the infection indicator of a country listed in Annex 1 is higher than 75.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Travelling from Estonia to other countries is allowed but please take into account that different restrictions might still be in place in your destination country.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: Schengen Area (without the UK)

description: Starting March 1, a special Covid-19 Estonian Health Board will contact those who may have been in close contact with the sick person and advise them to limit their social contacts. Where possible, people who have been potentially exposed to the virus are advised to voluntarily isolate themselves at home and monitor their health at all times.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 1, the Estonian Ministry of Health published precautionary measures to combat covid-19: If you have mild symptoms of a respiratory illness, carefully follow the usual rules of hand hygiene and stay at home until you recover. If you have a fever, cough, and difficulty breathing, get help early. Take care of your health and stay at home. Call your general practitioner. If you do not have access to a GP, call the GP hotline on 1220.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From Monday, March 16, 2020, according to recent measures implemented by the Estonian government due to the COVID-19 pandemic, individuals can temporarily apply for sick leave online. This is a response to the increased workload faced by family doctors and the healthcare system, which has made it more challenging to schedule appointments. To obtain an official sick note, individuals can utilize various platforms, including the Patient Portal, the Health Insurance Fund (Haigekassa), the family doctors association (perearstide selts), and the health and well-being center (Tervise ja Heaolu Infosüsteemide Keskus).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Starting from April 11, 2020, drones operated in conjunction with the Tallinn Municipal Police (MuPo), auxiliary police officers and private security firm USS, are being used to monitor 2+2 public gathering rules in Tallinn. The PPA (Police and Border Guard Board) expresses concern regarding the non-compliance with the regulations, particularly among young individuals congregating in parks located in Lasnamäe, Tallinn's largest residential district, who tend to "forget" the implemented rules. Therefore, in an attempt to scatter groups of young people and identify those in the vicinity, drones are deployed to fly directly amidst them, capturing footage with onboard cameras.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: A person’s absolute (e.g. GPS) location over time
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: From 1st May 2020, in Estonia, those who fall sick are instructed to inform their employer, who should establish that person's immediate contacts and instruct them to self-isolate for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 18 May 2020, if people in Estonia have received a close contact notification from the Health Board, the HOIA application or the patient they came in contact with, it is important that they remain self-contained. A person assigned to self-isolation may not go to work, school or public places or use public transport. Due to the latency period for COVID-19 infectious disease, the government of Estonia asks people to stay at home for 10 days from close contact and monitor their health. Although testing is not mandatory, the Health Board recommends that close contacts undergo SARS-CoV-2 testing at the end of the 10-calendar-day quarantine period to detect possible asymptomatic disease.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From Monday, March 16, 2020, according to recent measures implemented by the Estonian government due to the COVID-19 pandemic, individuals can temporarily apply for sick leave online. This is a response to the increased workload faced by family doctors and the healthcare system, which has made it more challenging to schedule appointments. To obtain an official sick note, individuals can utilize various platforms, including the Patient Portal, the Health Insurance Fund (Haigekassa), the family doctors association (perearstide selts), and the health and well-being center (Tervise ja Heaolu Infosüsteemide Keskus). UPDATE: Beginning from May 25, 2020, patients can no longer be able to file their own sick leave certificates. They will need to reach out to their doctors.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 20, 2020, the Estonian government released the contact tracing app "Hoia". It was created between the Ministry of Social Affairs (Sotsiaalministeerium), the Health and Welfare Information Systems Center (Tervise ja Heaolu Infosüsteemide Keskus) and 12 Estonian companies. The purpose of this app is notifying individuals who have come into close contact with someone infected with the virus and offering them guidance on the necessary steps to take if they have been exposed. Its objective is to halt the spread of the virus by alerting and advising those who have been in proximity to seek medical attention and take precautionary actions.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting March 19, 2020, the Estonian government has decided that health care professionals with the right to prescribe medicinal products are allowed to prescribe medicinal products for chronic diseases for no more than two months at a time.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting March 19, 2020, the Estonian government imposed restrictions on how pharmacies are allowed to dispense medicinal products. For repeat prescriptions, pharmacies may only dispense one prescription at a time and the prescription should cover no more than the customer's needs two months into the future. For over-the-counter medicinal products, no more than two packagings per proprietary medicinal product and per one customer are allowed. Pharmacies should only dispense medicinal products if the medicinal products already purchased do not suffice for the next two months of treatment or until the end of treatment, or if the life or health of a person would be compromised by non-dispensing of a medicinal product.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting from March 26th, 2020, the Estonian Board of Health suspends planned treatment outside the national hospital network to prevent the spread of the COVID-19 infection. description:

Private medical facilities and dental clinics will continue to provide only emergency care. Planned treatment activities are stopped in order to prevent the spread of infection and save personal protective equipment. UPDATE: "Estonia, March 11, 2021:
The National Government declares that grocery stores, pharmacies, stores where technical aids and medical devices are sold or rented on the basis of a technical aid card or medical device card, points of sale of telecommunications companies, optics stores, pet stores, petrol stations, or public spaces of commercial establishments and places of provision of services that are necessary for ensuring access to the aforementioned, may open if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. There are exceptions.
The policy is slated to end on April 11, 2021."

description: On 16 April 2020, the government decided to support two sero-epidemiological studies in Estonia to determine the extent of the spread of coronavirus in the country. Testing will be carried out under the research project of the COVID-19 monitoring system and will be carried out by the research team of the University of Tartu. People will be selected based on random selection for testing across Estonia. Weekly, 2,000 people will be tested, regardless if they have symptoms or not, so it would be possible to assess the spread of the infection across the country in different counties and population groups.

description: The Health Board recommends disinfecting the door handles, handrails, elevator buttons etc. of apartment buildings at least once a day. Viruses are destroyed by a disinfectant that contains at least 70  ethanol. Hallways have to be cleaned with water and water-absorbent cloth because cleaning dust with a dry brush will not get rid of the virus. When cleaning it is important to use disposable gloves and easy-to-clean working clothes and footwear in order to protect yourself from chemical cleaning agents and contamination on surfaces. If possible, the apartment associations could provide hand-sanitisers near entrances and lifts. You should, however, definitely remember to wash your hands thoroughly after coming home.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: At the briefing on May 12, MoH of Estonia again reminded that It is still always important to guarantee adequate air exchange in rooms to reduce the amount of virus particles in the rooms of both sick and healthy people. For this we recommend To air your living spaces regularly In public spaces, to guarantee a good round-the-clock air exchange that would not allow the virus particles and contaminants to accumulate.In non-residential premises and social welfare institutions, the ventilation system must not be switched off even if the building is not in use. The ventilation system must also operate at evenings and weekends at with either design capacity or normal daily regime 100 or reduced capacity at least 40 . The ventilation system operating with reduced capacity must be switched to the design capacity regime at least two hours before the building or part of the building will be used. Circulating air ventilation systems are in use in storehouses and shopping centres. They must be fully switched onto the external air injection to avoid possible virus circulation through the ventilation system. In other ventilation systems, the air injection and extraction settings must be reviewed so that the system sends the air exhaust out without recirculating it. If the building does not have an air conditioning and ventilation system that guarantees suitable indoor climate, the rooms must be actively aired. This should be done at least once an hour and within 15 minutes before people ar
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
August 10, 2020. Estonia.
Both the Health Board and the government in Estonia are in agreement that making face masks mandatory in public is unnecessary to control the spread of the coronavirus. They believe that research on mask usage has been controversial, and improper wearing of masks may do more harm than good. Instead, they recommend the use of masks for individuals who have tested positive for the virus and need to go out for essential reasons, as well as for those who have been in close proximity to an infected person or find themselves in enclosed and crowded public spaces like public transport. Hanna Sepp, chief specialist at the Health Board, emphasized that face masks should only be recommended in such specific situations and not mandated.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting from April 28, 2020, persons permanently or temporarily living in Estonian rural municipalities of Saaremaa, Hiiumaa, Vormsi, Ruhnu, Kihnu, and Muhu, and the island of Manija, that were previously put under movement restriction, are now allowed to issue one-time permits to travel from the territory of the corresponding rural municipality or island to the mainland, and from the mainland back to the territory of the rural municipality or island. Following breakdown of permits per day applies: 25 permits for Saaremaa, 5 permits for Muhu, 20 permits for Hiiumaa, and 10 permits for Kihnu, Ruhnu and Vormsi each.

description: Strating from March 30, 2020, in Estonia the residents of the Saarema and Muhu islands must remain in their homes, except for essential reasons. They are permitted to visit the grocery store, pharmacy, and doctor. Going to the workplace is allowed only if remote work is not feasible. Parents are allowed to take and pick up their children from kindergarten. Additionally, they can provide care for the elderly, disabled, or those requiring assistance while ensuring the use of personal protective equipment when doing so. Those who fail to comply with the implemented measures will receive a warning from the police. If the warning proves ineffective, the next step will involve imposing a fine of up to 2000 Euros as a penalty.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: April 3rd 2020, the Estonian prime minister signed an order to protect people from COVID-19 infection at care homes. People receiving 24h special care service and a general care service are not allowed to leave the territory of the care home until the end of the emergency situation. These rules doesnt apply to people without symptoms (who can go home from a care home, understanding they cannot return until the end of the emergency situation), the employees in and the owner or a representative of the owner of the area covered by the restriction on movement, and persons carrying out official duties.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: April 17, 2020. Estonia. Six students from the University of Tartu, residing in a dormitory on Raatuse Street, have received positive results for the coronavirus. As a precautionary measure, the Health Board has decided to put the building in complete lockdown.  All residents of the dormitory are required to stay inside their apartments until they receive the results of their COVID-19 tests. Additionally, they must wait until all close contacts of the infected individuals have been identified, and their test results are also obtained. Students who have tested positive for the virus must undergo self-isolation until they have fully recovered. Those who have been in close contact with infected individuals and have tested negative for COVID-19 will still need to stay in their dormitory apartments for two weeks. During this period, they must monitor their health status but will be allowed to go outside for fresh air if needed.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On March 25, the government announced that it would provide the Estonian Health Insurance Fund (EHIF) with at least 200 million euros over three months to cover emergency expenses related to the coronavirus. In addition, more than 20 million euros have already been allocated for the purchase of personal protective equipment, respirators and coronavirus testing equipment.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_text: Economy policy
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The majority of shops will close and new movement restrictions will be introduced in Saaremaa and Muhu in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) and limit the burden on the health system, Prime Minister Jüri Ratas, who is in charge of the emergency situation, announced late on Saturday night. Stricter restrictions on movement will go into force on Monday (March 30). People must carry ID when they leave the house and the police will be carrying out spot checks. Fines of up to €2,000 can now be issued.  A general 2+2 rule applies to moving around outside, according to which only 2 people can be in a public space together and a 2 metre distance must be kept from others.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: Government control and monitoring of Saaremaa and Muhu residents
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Estonia joins statement on safety of journalists and access to information during the COVID-19 crisis15. April 2020 - 16:40Everyone has the right to comprehensible, accessible, timely and reliable information concerning the nature and level of the threat COVID-19 poses to their health, allowing them to follow evidence-based guidance on how to stay safe.We welcome a range of initiatives aimed at supporting journalists’ and media workers’ safety in the light of COVID-19 undertaken by international organisations, such as UNESCO and civil society, media associations as well as social media companies.

description:
Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 – As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders during the e-sessions of the Government. 
First, the Government approved the order to continue to restrict the sale of alcohol at all places selling alcohol, including restaurants and bars, from 22:00 to 10:00. The restrictions do not apply on board of a ship or an aircraft used for international passenger transport and to a sales premises located in the security area of the international airport or port. The restriction on the sale of alcohol applies to catering establishments, including bars and other similar sales premises until July 1.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: RESTRICTIONS TO ALCOHOL SALES
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 – As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders.Public religious services and other religious rites are allowed if the 2+2 rule is complied with and the provision of disinfectants is guaranteed.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_text: Easing the restrictions on gatherings for religious events
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 When visiting museums and exhibition institutions, the 2+2 rule must be observed; for visiting groups, there may be a maximum of ten visitors in the group; the availability of disinfectants must be ensured. The surfaces frequently touched by visitors must be cleaned frequently. If possible, the organiser offers digital information materials instead of physical materials. Creative workshops will not be organised using commonly used tools or, if organised, they will be disinfected after each user.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: Monitoring of the vents in museums and exhibition institutions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 – As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders during the e-sessions of the Government yesterday, confirming restrictions and easing of restrictions in force after the end of the emergency situation.
Until June 30, all public events are prohibited.
As an exception, public events are allowed in the open air, where visitors are in their cars, such as drive-in cinemas and concerts. The organiser of the event must ensure that the 2+2 rule is observed, the participants must not leave the car without an unavoidable reason and the distance between parked cars must remain sufficient. If necessary, the organiser of the event must ensure the provision of disinfectants on the spot.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: Allowance of some public events in the open air
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 1 June, Estonia allows entry to individuals without symptoms arriving from a member state of the European Union or the Schengen area or the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

description: Tallinn, Stenbock House, 11 June 2020 – The government clarified its previous order and provided that a person arriving in Estonia from a country with a higher COVID-19 infection rate would be subject to a 14-day restriction on freedom of movement. Quarantine was previously required, but for the sake of legal clarity, the wording of the order was clarified by adding a restriction on freedom of movement.Similarly to the current regulation, the specified order stipulates that the restriction of freedom of movement is applied during the latent period of infection, or 14 days. This means a prohibition on leaving the place of residence or permanent residence, except on the instructions of a healthcare professional or a police officer or in the event of an emergency endangering a person’s life or health. People can also leave home to receive healthcare services or if it is not possible to obtain food, basic necessities, or medicine in any other way.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: The restriction on freedom of movement after crossing state borders
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Tallinn, Stenbock House, 18 June 2020 – As of 19 June, the government has decided to replace the 2+2 rule with a requirement for people to disperse. This means that a safe distance between people must continue to be maintained, but the state no longer requires compliance with the 2+2 rule.Dispersion requirements will replace the 2+2 rule in all public spaces, such as stores, service points and public-use spaces at shopping centres, as well as at casinos and slot machine locations. In place of the 2+2 rule, dispersion must also be ensured at public events, public meetings and religious services.The requirement will apply to public saunas, spas, swimming pools and water parks, as well as bowling, billiards and children's playrooms. Along with the organisation of activities in basic schools, upper secondary schools, vocational schools and institutes of higher education, training centres, hobby schools, recreational activity providers, and public youth centres. It will also be in place at children's and student camps, sports and museum and exhibition visits.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_text: Social distancing of 2 meters is replaced by dispersing.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: What has caused the latest increase in new infections of COVID in Estonia, where over the past day to Tuesday, August 4, 11 new cases have been registered? Epidemiologists have traced four of the infections to a night club in Tartu. Estonian public health officials encouraged the population to continue observing hand hygiene, social distancing and staying home, when sick, as key measures to prevent the second wave of COVID-19, ERR reports.

description: Tallinn, Stenbock House, 28 August 2020 – Government members approved a conceptual decision to continue with the current air travel restrictions for countries where the COVID-19 infection rate has been 25 or higher per 100,000 people in the last 14 days. Exceptions to these restrictions were established for scheduled flights to the following destinations: Frankfurt, Helsinki, Copenhagen, London, Riga, and Warsaw. These cities are open for travelling from the Tallinn Airport regardless of the prevalence rates. Acceptable destinations are also countries where the prevalence rate per 100,000 people remains under 25 people.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: Easing travel restrictions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Republic of EstoniaMinistry of Foreign AffairsStarting from 1 September, people with a negative COVID-19 test arriving from countries with an increased risk of infection (with an infection rate exceeding 16 and marked as red or countries not included in the following list https://vm.ee/en/information-countries-and-self-isolation-requirements-p...) are permitted to go to work if it is absolutely crucial, and on the condition that they immediately test negative for the virus on their arrival. All contact with other people must be avoided while waiting for the test results. In case of a negative test result, the restriction on the freedom of movement applies for the first seven days, i.e. it is allowed to go to work or shop for essentials in case of emergencies but non-essential contacts should be avoided. They must take a second test no earlier than 7 days after the first test and if the test is also negative, they are free to continue their everyday life. This means that the 14-day restriction on the freedom of movement does not apply to them after two negative tests.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: Easing quarantine restrictions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description: 12.08.2020 17:23LikeA class in progress at Pelgulinn high school in pre-pandemic days.A class in progress at Pelgulinn high school in pre-pandemic days. Source: ERRThe Ministry of Education has said that guidelines it is providing to schools ahead of the academic year starting on September 1 are just that, and not mandatory responsibilities, adding that these have taken on board lessons learned during the spring coronavirus peak and are aimed at avoiding a return to remote learning.Estonian schools have not had in-classroom teaching since March, due to the pandemic. After some discussion about schools returning early, in mid-August, for the 2020-2021 academic year, the decision was made to stick to the traditional September 1 first day of school.

description: Estonia and Singapore are co-sponsoring a Global Declaration on the Digital Response to COVID-19, “Close the Digital Divides: the Digital Response to COVID-19”. The declaration was launched at a videoconference at the level of Foreign Ministers on Wednesday, 1 July 2020. The aim of this Ministerial Conference was to provide an opportunity to discuss how countries can emerge stronger and better equipped from the COVID-19 crisis by using innovative and flexible digital solutions, and working together as a global family.

description:
Estonia, March 17, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who are allowed to enter Estonia at the state border need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. There are various exceptions such as for employees of diplomatic missions if they're asymptomatic.
This policy is valid until further notice and its necessity is evaluated every two weeks at the latest.

description:
Estonia, March 28, 2020:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with the coronavirus and those permanently residing with them are prohibited from leaving their place of residence or permanent place of stay until the recovery of the diagnosed person. People who have been diagnosed may only leave their residence or permanent place of stay under specific circumstances: if a healthcare professional or a police officer orders them to do so, or in situations where there is an emergency that poses a threat to their life or health.

description: The Government approved an order extending the restrictions on crossing the Estonian state border and 14-day quarantine requirement for persons who had previously been subject to this requirement. From 18th May 2020, Latvian or Lithuanian citizens, holders of residence permits, or persons with a right of residence in these countries who have no symptoms of the disease, may enter Estonia without an obligation for quarantine. Additionally, Finnish citizens, holders of residence permits or persons with a right of residence in Finland, who have no symptoms of the disease, who come to Estonia to work, study or for unavoidable family reasons such as meeting with their close relatives, attending a funeral or a wedding, or need to visit due to a case of illness, can also enter Estonia. People without symptoms of the disease, who have had the right to enter Estonia previously without an obligation to stay in quarantine, may continue to do so. For example, people transporting goods and raw materials, persons involved in the international carriage of cargo and passengers, persons involved in the technical work of a company operating in Estonia, health care providers, diplomats, people arriving within the framework of international military cooperation, etc.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

From 18th May 2020, Latvian or Lithuanian citizens, holders of residence permits, or persons with a right of residence in these countries who have no symptoms of the disease, may enter Estonia without an obligation for quarantine. Additionally, Finnish citizens, holders of residence permits or persons with a right of residence in Finland, who have no symptoms of the disease, who come to Estonia to work, study or for unavoidable family reasons such as meeting with their close relatives, attending a funeral or a wedding, or need to visit due to a case of illness, can also enter Estonia. People without symptoms of the disease, who have had the right to enter Estonia previously without an obligation to stay in quarantine, may continue to do so. For example, people transporting goods and raw materials, persons involved in the international carriage of cargo and passengers, persons involved in the technical work of a company operating in Estonia, health care providers, diplomats, people arriving within the framework of international military cooperation, etc.

 UPDATE: From January 15, 2021, as per ERR News, "[t]he infection rate limit for a "safe country" has been raised to 150 per 100,000 inhabitants in a two weeks period and arrivals traveling to Estonia from those countries do not need to quarantine. As of Friday, countries which fall below that threshold are Finland, Greece and Iceland."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 – As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18 2020, the Estonian Government approved four orders. 
Secondly, the Government confirmed the order to establish quarantine after the end of the emergency situation for COVID-19 patients and people living with them who are in close contact with the patients.
People infected with COVID-19 are prohibited from leaving their place of residence from the time of diagnosis until recovery. This also applies to the people using shelters and other such services who must remain in quarantine at their place of stay.

People in close contact with infected persons may move outside their residence to a limited extent only if they have no symptoms of the disease.  It is allowed to leave the home if it is unavoidable, and for spending some time outdoors, if all the measures are taken to prevent the spread of the disease, and instructions of the Health Board are observed.

The person may also leave their residence if they have received an order from a health care worker or a police officer instructing them to leave the place of residence or permanent stay, or in the event of an emergency which threatens the person's life or health.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People with certain health conditions (please note which health conditions in the text entry),Other population not specifed above

description:
Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 – As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18 2020, the Government approved four orders. 
- extending the restrictions on crossing the Estonian state border. 

-extending the restrictions  on crossing the Estonian state border and 14-day quarantine requirement for persons who had previously been subject to this requirement.

-Latvian or Lithuanian citizens, holders of residence permits, or persons with a right of residence in these countries who have no symptoms of the disease, may enter Estonia without an obligation for quarantine. 

-Finnish citizens, holders of residence permits or persons with a right of residence in Finland, who have no symptoms of the disease, who come to Estonia to work, study or for unavoidable family reasons such as meeting with their close relatives, attending a funeral or a wedding, or need to visit due to a case of illness, can also enter Estonia.

-A foreign national without any symptoms of the disease, traveling to their home country is also allowed to transit through Estonia.

-People without symptoms of the disease, who have had the right to enter Estonia previously without an obligation to stay in quarantine, may continue to do so.

This policy is slated to end on July 1, 2020.

description: From 1 June, Estonia allows entry to individuals without symptoms arriving from a member state of the European Union or the Schengen area, or the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. Mandatory self-isolation for passengers arriving in Estonia depends on whether the coronavirus infection rate in their country of departure is above 15. If the infection rate is below 15, you will not be required to self-isolate, if it is above 15, you will need to remain in self-isolation.

description:

The National Government declares that persons who are allowed to enter Estonia at the state border need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. There are various exceptions for asymptomatic persons.
The policy's ending is indefinite. UPDATE: From June 1, 2020, there are additional exceptions for, among other things, asymptomatic persons "who have been in a Member State of the European Union or a Schengen Member State or the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland within the past 14 days, provided the cumulative number of positive tests for the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 causing the COVID-19 disease per 100,000 inhabitants in said country for the past 14 days is equal to or less than 15".

description:
From 1 June2020, Estonia allows entry to individuals without symptoms arriving from a member state of the European Union or the Schengen area, or the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. Mandatory self-isolation for passengers arriving in Estonia depends on whether the coronavirus infection rate in their country of departure is above 15. If the infection rate is below 15, you will not be required to self-isolate, if it is above 15, you will need to remain in self-isolation. UPDATE: From June 1, 2021, persons who have completed the vaccination series for COVID-19 or been given one dose of vaccine after recovering from COVID-19, have developed full protection after the last dose of vaccine and no more than one year has passed since, are exempted from quarantine rules. Exceptions now also apply to a person who has contracted COVID-19 after the first dose of vaccine and no more than one year has passed since the person was declared healthy by a physician (they are considered a "recovered person" if having contracted COVID-19 within two weeks after the first dose of vaccine).
From June 21, 2021, "self-quarantine will not be applied to asymptomatic persons who arrive in Estonia from a third country where the cumulative number of positive tests for the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 causing COVID-19 per 100,000 inhabitants for the past 14 days is equal to or less than 75" (previously, the number was 16).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Stenbock House, 6 July 2020 - Upon arrival from countries outside the European Union where the number of infected persons per 100,000 people is more than 16, people entering Estonia for the purpose of work or study must remain in isolation, which is organized in cooperation with the employer or educational institution, respectively. Both transport and living during the 14-day period of self-isolation must be ensured. The 14-day restriction on staying at the place of residence or stay applies to people who come here through the EU or Schengen countries with an infection rate of more than 16 per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days (flexibility 10 percent).

description: Starting from July 6, 2020, by order of the Estonian Ministry of Health, upon arrival from countries outside the European Union, where the number of infections per 100,000 people exceeds 16, persons entering Estonia for the purpose of work or study must remain in isolation. It is necessary to provide both transport and accommodation during the 14-day self-isolation period, as well as two tests for coronavirus, one of which is carried out upon arrival in Estonia, and the other on the 14th day of stay. An employee can start working in Estonia on the 15th day of their stay in Estonia if the second test is negative.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, July 13, 2020:
As per SchengenVisaInfo.com, the Estonian Ministry of Interior declares that travellers from Sweden, Portugal, Romania, Bulgaria, Croatia, the Czech Republic and Luxembourg have to self-isolate for two weeks after entering Estonia. Additionally, arrivals from Montenegro and Serbia have to quarantine if they come from countries other than the approved 14 countries. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 16 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. There are exceptions.
The current list of countries subject to mandatory self-isolation is valid until July 19, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Estonia, July 16, 2020:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 and those permanently residing with them are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until the recovery of the diagnosed person, which is decided by a physician. There are various exceptions such as if there is an order to leave one's quarantine location.
This policy is slated to end on September 30, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Asylum/refugee seekers,Homeless population,Other population not specifed above
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Stenbock House, 16 July 2020 – the Estonian government renewed the quarantine requirements applicable to people diagnosed with COVID-19 and people living with them or permanently staying in the same place of residence, with a new term of 30 September 2020. As previously, people diagnosed with COVID-19 are forbidden from leaving their place of residence or permanent place of stay until their illness has ended, except at the order of a healthcare worker or police officer or in an emergency endangering the person’s life or health.
The place of provision of a shelter or safe house service is also considered a place of residence or permanent place of stay.
People in close contact with the infected person who live with them or are permanently staying in the same place of residence may leave their place of residence only on limited occasions if they have no symptoms of illness and if they are a healthcare worker or a person performing public duties carrying out their work assignments if they monitor their health carefully and abide by the measures established by the government or Health Board to prevent the possible spread of the infectious disease. ...people in close contact with the infected person may leave their home to acquire things required for everyday life and to spend time outside, provided that they take all measures to prevent the possible spread of the infectious disease, as well as if any contact with a person diagnosed with COVID is prevented.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
