description:
Estonia, July 27, 2020:
The list of risk countries for which quarantine requirements apply is updated. Now, a two-week restriction on freedom of movement will apply to people arriving in Estonia from all countries except, as for European countries, Austria, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, San Marino, Slovakia, Slovenia, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, and the Vatican City, as well as, as for third countries, Algeria, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Morocco, New Zealand, South Korea, Rwanda, Thailand, Tunisia, and Uruguay. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from European countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 16 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. For third countries, recommendations of the Council of the European Union are followed. There are exceptions.
The current list of countries subject to mandatory self-isolation is valid until August 2, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Aug 7, 2020. Estonia has allowed its higher education institutions to welcome students from abroad, yet depending on their country of origin they will be required to go into self-isolation. The Education and Research Minister explained: «In the regulation that allows foreign students to enter the country /…/, it is written that if they break the 14-day quarantine period, they will lose the right to remain in Estonia.»

The National Government declares that persons who are allowed to enter Estonia at the state border need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. There are various exceptions for asymptomatic persons.

description:
Estonia, August 19, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From August 28, 2020, there are exceptions for "members of foreign delegations arriving in Estonia for official meetings on the invitation of a state or local authority".
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Estonia, August 31, 2020:
The list of risk countries for which quarantine requirements apply is updated. Now, a two-week restriction on freedom of movement will apply to people arriving in Estonia from all countries except, as for European countries, Finland, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Norway, San Marino, Slovakia, Vatican, as well as, as for third countries, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from European countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 16 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. For third countries, recommendations of the Council of the European Union are followed. There are exceptions.
The current list of countries subject to mandatory self-isolation is valid until September 6, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On the 28th of September the Estonian government's policy stating that If the infection rate is above 25 / 100 000 inhabitants in Finland, Latvia and Lithuania, the travellers from the country in question are required to quarantine for 14 days was amended so that Latvia, Lithuania and Finland are exempt from self-isolation in certain cases if the infection rate of these countries rises above 25. People arriving in Estonia from these countries are not required to self-isolate for two weeks if they are coming here to work, study, access healthcare services, attend a family event or for the purposes of transit, and they exhibit no symptoms or have had no known contact with an infected person. UPDATE: The original policy set that if the number of infections in Finland, Latvia or Lithuania was over 25 per 100 000 inhabitants, all travellers from these countries were required to quarantine for 14 days. Now the rules have been relaxed so that the traveller can be exempted from the 14 day self-isolation under certain circumstances. These include if they are coming to Estonia to work, study, access healthcare services, attend a family event or for the purposes of transit, and they exhibit no symptoms or have had no known contact with an infected person.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia, September 1, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 7 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From September 28, 2020, if the cumulative number of positive tests for the coronavirus per 100,000 inhabitants for the past 14 days is greater than 25 in Lithuania, Latvia or Finland, individuals may be exempted from quarantine rules if they arrive from these countries for the purpose of working, studying or receiving health services or for family reasons or transit (previously, there were no exemptions above the threshold of 25).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
From 28th of September the rules for self-isolation for travellers from Finland, Latvia and Lithuania have been relaxed so that the traveller can be exempted from the 14 day self-isolation under certain circumstances. These include if they are coming to Estonia to work, study, access healthcare services, attend a family event or for the purposes of transit, and they exhibit no symptoms or have had no known contact with an infected person. UPDATE: From June 21, 2021 self-quarantine will not be applied to asymptomatic persons who arrive in Estonia from a third country where the cumulative number of positive tests for the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 causing COVID-19 per 100,000 inhabitants for the past 14 days is equal to or less than 75
From July 19, 2021, tests are specified to reduce the quarantine period. The decree now explicitly mentions the use of SARS-CoV-2 antigen RTD tests and SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR tests.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia, September 1, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 7 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From September 29, 2020, there are exceptions for those "who participate in an international championship as an athlete or an athlete’s team member or who [are] directly involved in carrying out aforesaid sports competition".
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Estonia, August 19, 2020:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 and those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with them are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until the recovery of the diagnosed person, which is decided by a physician. There are various exceptions such as if there is an order to leave one's quarantine location.
This policy is slated to end on September 30, 2020. UPDATE: From October 1, 2020, this policy is extended until December 31, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Asylum/refugee seekers,Homeless population,Other population not specifed above

description:
Estonia, October 12, 2020:
The list of risk countries for which quarantine requirements apply is updated. Now, a two-week restriction on freedom of movement will apply to people arriving in Estonia from all countries except, as for European countries, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Finland, Germany, Greece, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Norway, Vatican, as well as, as for third countries, Australia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Uruguay. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from European countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 50 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. For third countries, recommendations of the Council of the European Union are followed. There are exceptions.
The current list of countries subject to mandatory self-isolation is valid until October 18, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, September 1, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 7 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From October 12, 2020, the infection rate threshold for European countries, starting from which people arriving from there will be subject to a self-quarantine period of 14 days, is raised to 50. If this number is greater than 50 for Lithuania, Latvia or Finland, only those arriving for the purpose of working, studying or receiving health services or for family reasons or transit may be exempted. There are now also exceptions for Valga/Valka residents.

description:
Estonia, September 1, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 7 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From October 19, 2020, if the cumulative number of positive tests for the coronavirus per 100,000 inhabitants for the past 14 days in Lithuania, Latvia or Finland is over 10% greater than the number for Estonia or greater than 50, individuals may be exempted from quarantine rules if they submit a negative test result taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in the country. Those who arrive for the purpose of working, studying or receiving health services or for family reasons or transit may take a test after arrival in Estonia and must stay in their place of residence or permanent place of stay until finding out that their test was negative.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Estonia, October 30, 2020:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 14 days after the last close contact. There are various exceptions such as if there is an order to leave one's quarantine location. Contact persons may stop quarantining after 10 days by means of a negative test result, if certified by a physician as being free of infection or if so decided by authorities.
This policy is slated to end on December 31, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

This policy is slated to end on September 30, 2020. UPDATE: From October 30, 2020, contact persons of diagnosed individuals may stop quarantining 14 calendar days after the last close contact.

description:
Estonia, November 2, 2020:
The list of risk countries for which quarantine requirements apply is updated. Now, a two-week restriction on freedom of movement will apply to people arriving in Estonia from all countries except, as for European countries, Finland, as well as, as for third countries, Australia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Singapur. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from European countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 50 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. For third countries, recommendations of the Council of the European Union are followed. There are exceptions.
The current list of countries subject to mandatory self-isolation is valid until November 8, 2020.

description:
Estonia, October 30, 2020:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 14 days after the last close contact. There are various exceptions such as if there is an order to leave one's quarantine location. Contact persons may stop quarantining after 10 days by means of a negative test result, if certified by a physician as being free of infection or if so decided by authorities.
This policy is slated to end on December 31, 2020. UPDATE: From November 26, 2020, until December 1, 2020, there are additional exceptions for contact persons participating in the European Men's Basketball Championship qualification tournament.

description: Starting from Friday, January 15, 2021, there will be a 10-day restriction on freedom of movement for individuals arriving to Estonia from European Union, European Economic Area, or Schengen area countries with an infection rate exceeding 150 per 100,000 inhabitants. This restriction will be in effect from January 15 to January 24. The countries affected by these restrictions during this period include Andorra, Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Spain, the Netherlands, Croatia, Ireland, Italy, Cyprus, Lithuania, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Latvia, Malta, Monaco, Norway, Poland, Portugal, France, Sweden, Romania, Germany, San Marino, Slovakia, Slovenia, Switzerland, Denmark, Czech Republic, and Hungary.

Also, quarantine may now be ended after 6 days by means of two negative test results. Compliance with the policy is eased as per sections 3 and 4 of the (new) source document. Among other things, the infection rate threshold for the UK, starting from which people arriving from there will be subject to a self-quarantine period of 10 days, is raised to 150.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Estonia, September 1, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 7 days by means of two negative test results (one upon arrival and the other on the 7th day of quarantine). There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From January 15, 2021, quarantine may already be ended after 6 days by means of two negative test results. Also, the infection rate threshold for European countries as per section 4, number 10 of the (new) source document, starting from which people arriving from there will be subject to a self-quarantine period of 10 days, is raised to 150. If the cumulative number of positive tests for the coronavirus per 100,000 inhabitants for the past 14 days in Lithuania, Latvia or Finland is greater than 150, individuals from there may be exempted from quarantine rules if they submit a negative test result taken promptly after arrival in the country. Until the test has come back negative the person is required to remain in their place of residence or permanent place of stay.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Estonia, December 28, 2020:
The list of risk countries for which quarantine requirements apply is updated. Now, a two-week restriction on freedom of movement will apply to people arriving in Estonia from all countries except, as for European countries, Iceland, as well as, as for third countries, Australia, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from European countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 50 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. For third countries, recommendations of the Council of the European Union are followed. There are exceptions.
The current list of countries subject to mandatory self-isolation is valid until January 3, 2021. UPDATE: From January 15, 2021, as per ERR News, "[t]he infection rate limit for a "safe country" has been raised to 150 per 100,000 inhabitants in a two weeks period and arrivals traveling to Estonia from those countries do not need to quarantine. As of Friday, countries which fall below that threshold are Finland, Greece and Iceland."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, February 2, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. There are various exceptions such as for contact persons who have recovered from or have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
This policy is slated to end on May 31, 2021.

description:
Estonia, January 1, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 14 days. There are various exceptions such as if there is an order to leave one's quarantine location. Contact persons may stop quarantining after 10 days by means of a negative test result (for more details, see section 5 of the source document).
This policy is slated to end on February 1, 2021. UPDATE: From February 2, 2021, there is no longer the possibility of shortening the quarantine period to 10 days by means of a negative test result.

description:
Estonia, December 28, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia from the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 7 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From April 5, 2021, the UK is no longer treated separately in terms of quarantine rules: "The special regulation established in January 2021 for people arriving from the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland is [...] revoked based on the fact that the strain of COVID-19 that originated in the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland has become prevalent in Estonia".
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: The Estonian Ministry of Health, together with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, has announced that starting from April 26, if a student was abroad during school holidays, he is subject to a 10-day self-isolation period or two PCR tests for coronavirus at least six days apart. The first test can be taken in a foreign country no later than 72 hours before arrival in Estonia or immediately after entering Estonia. Students and youth can only return to school and clubs after a second negative test result. There are some countries that are not subject to the ''''''' self-isolation obligation, a list of which is available on the website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. When entering Estonia, you must fill out a border crossing declaration.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Estonia, April 5, 2021:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 10 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 6 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From May 3, 2021, there are additional exceptions for asymptomatic persons "who cross the state border between the Republic of Estonia and the Republic of Latvia at least twice a week for the purpose of urgent cross-border work or studies, provided the relevant person has taken at least one test for the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 causing COVID-19 during the past seven days and the results of that test have come back negative or a physician has declared the person not to be contagious".
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Estonia, February 2, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. There are various exceptions such as for contact persons who have recovered from or have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
This policy is slated to end on May 31, 2021. UPDATE: From May 22, 2021, there are additional exceptions for contact persons participating in the European Golden League - Men volleyball tournament.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Asylum/refugee seekers,Homeless population,People who are neither vaccinated nor recovered from COVID-19
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Estonia, April 5, 2021:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 10 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 6 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From June 1, 2021, persons who have completed the vaccination series for COVID-19 or been given one dose of vaccine after recovering from COVID-19, have developed full protection after the last dose of vaccine and no more than one year has passed since, are exempted from quarantine rules. Exceptions now also apply to a person who has contracted COVID-19 after the first dose of vaccine and no more than one year has passed since the person was declared healthy by a physician (they are considered a "recovered person" if having contracted COVID-19 within two weeks after the first dose of vaccine).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Estonia, June 1, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that infected persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. There are various exceptions such as for contact persons who have recovered from or have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
This policy is slated to end on December 31, 2021. UPDATE: From June 2, 2021, conditions for contact persons in order to be exempted (as per section 7 of the respective order) are repealed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, June 14, 2021:
The list of risk countries for which quarantine requirements apply is updated. Now, a two-week restriction on freedom of movement will apply to people arriving in Estonia from all countries except, as for European countries, Austria, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Cyprus, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, San Marino, Slovakia, Spain, Switzerland, UK, Vatican, as well as, as for third countries, Australia, Israel, Japan, New Zealand, South Korea, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from European countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 150 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. For third countries, recommendations of the Council of the European Union are followed. There are exceptions.
The current list of countries subject to mandatory self-isolation is valid until June 20, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: The Baltic country of Estonia has imposed stricter entry restrictions on arrivals from Spain. Starting from, July 12, "travellers from Spain are being quarantined in Estonia due to the increase in the number of COVID-19 cases in Spain." There is a ten-day restriction of freedom of movement after arrival in Estonia. That may be shortened by performing "a coronavirus PCR test abroad, up to 72 hours before arrival in Estonia. While in Estonia, it is then possible to take a second test not earlier than on the sixth day after the first test taken abroad. A person is released from the ten-day isolation obligation ahead of time if the results of both tests are negative."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Baltic country of Estonia has imposed stricter entry restrictions on arrivals from Spain. Starting from, July 12, "travellers from Spain are being quarantined in Estonia due to the increase in the number of COVID-19 cases in Spain." There is a ten-day restriction of freedom of movement after arrival in Estonia. That may be shortened by performing "a coronavirus PCR test abroad, up to 72 hours before arrival in Estonia. While in Estonia, it is then possible to take a second test not earlier than on the sixth day after the first test taken abroad. A person is released from the ten-day isolation obligation ahead of time if the results of both tests are negative." UPDATE: Asymptomatic citizensfrom other countries can also come to Estonia to study, work or for purposes of tourism, sports, culture, etc.
A person is not subject to a movement restriction if he arrives into Estonia from a European Union, European Economic Area or Schengen area country where the infection indicator is less than 150 people per 100 000 residents within the past 14 days. If the indicator is higher, the person must adhere to the 10-day movement restriction.

Entering Estonia from outside the European Union, European Economic Area or Schengen area, for tourism, among other things, is allowed from countries listed in Annex 1 of the recommendation enacted by the Council of the European Union. The movement restriction applies if the infection indicator of a country listed in Annex 1 is higher than 75.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia, June 1, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that infected persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. There are various exceptions such as for contact persons who have recovered from or have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
This policy is slated to end on December 31, 2021. UPDATE: From July 19, 2021, a person is considered recovered if "no more than 180 days have passed since the SARS-CoV-2 test confirming the diagnosis was carried out or since the date of confirmation of the diagnosis" (previously, if "no more than six months have passed since the person was declared healthy"). The date of the SARS-CoV-2 test is now also decisive for those who may be a "person considered equal to a vaccinated person" (and not the date a person was declared healthy by a physician, as was previously the case).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, August 26, 2021:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 10 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 6 days by means of two negative test results (antigen and PCR tests). There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From November 3, 2021, those who have attained the age of 18 years may also be exempted from quarantine rules as per section 4, number 21 of the (new) source document (just as those up to 18 years of age): "Likewise, the words ‘and including’ are added to sub-clause 21) of clause 4 to specify the indicated age range. The current wording which reads ‘up to 18 years of age’ should be interpreted to mean that people 18 years of age are not covered by this regulation. However, the intention of this provision has been to also include people 18 years of age who participate in studies."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Estonia, June 1, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that infected persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. There are various exceptions such as for contact persons who have recovered from or have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
This policy is slated to end on December 31, 2021. UPDATE: From December 10, 2021, this policy is extended until March 31, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Asylum/refugee seekers,Homeless population,People who are neither vaccinated nor recovered from COVID-19
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

Estonia, January 10, 2022:

The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: 2022-04-04 (2): According to current information from Monday (4 April), travellers from Germany, the EU and the Schengen area generally no longer have to go into self-isolation after entering Estonia. This applies regardless of the vaccination status. The obligation to be tested is also no longer applicable. Only travellers from third countries must present proof of vaccination, a negative test result or proof of recovery

description:
Estonia, June 1, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that infected persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. There are various exceptions such as for contact persons who have recovered from or have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
This policy is slated to end on December 31, 2021. UPDATE: From February 1, 2022, contact persons are considered fully vaccinated and therefore exempted from quarantine rules if they have completed their vaccination series for COVID-19, have developed full protection after the last dose of a vaccine and no more than 270 days have passed (previously, it was one year) since the last dose of vaccine. Also, contact persons are now considered equal to a vaccinated person (and therefore also exempted from quarantine rules) if they have been given one dose of a vaccine after recovering from COVID-19 and have developed full protection after the dose and no more than 270 days have passed since (previously, it was also one year).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Asylum/refugee seekers,Homeless population,People who are neither vaccinated nor recovered from COVID-19
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Estonia, January 10, 2022:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 7 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From February 1, 2022, persons are exempted from the obligation to quarantine if they "ha[ve] completed the vaccination series for COVID-19, ha[ve] developed full protection after the last dose of vaccine and no more than 270 days have passed since the last dose of vaccine" (previously, it was one year). Also, persons are now considered equal to a vaccinated person if, among other things, "no more than 270 days have passed since the last dose of vaccine, or [...] no more than 270 days have passed since the SARS-CoV-2 test confirming the diagnosis was carried out or since the date of confirmation of the diagnosis" (previously, it was also one year).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Estonia, June 1, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that infected persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. There are various exceptions such as for contact persons who have recovered from or have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
This policy is slated to end on December 31, 2021. UPDATE: From February 7, 2022, infected persons may be exempted from quarantine rules if they are an employee of a health care provider to be performing urgent duties, if their symptoms are regressing and they take all measures imposed by the Health Board for preventing the spread of the coronavirus. Also, rules for children and juveniles to be exempted from quarantine rules are simplified and eased (for more details, see the source document).

description:
As of 12/03/2020 Additional restrictions have been introduced in order to help combat the spread of the COVID-19 virus, including those curtailing leisure activities. 

All sports halls, sports clubs, gyms, spas, saunas, swimming pools, water centers, day centers, and children´s playrooms are closed, by order of the prime minister, including those operated by hotels and other accommodation providers.

The restriction does not apply to the provision of social and health care services including food aid, social welfare services, medical and rehabilitation services.

description:
Under the orders of Prime Minister Jüri Ratas (Center), carrying executive power over the emergency situation declared on Thursday evening in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic, only permanent residents of Estonia's western islands of Hiiumaa, Kihnu, Muhu, Ruhnu, Saarema and Vormsi are permitted to access the islands. Additional restrictions have been introduced in order to help combat the spread of the COVID-19 virus, including those curtailing leisure activities. 

All sports halls, sports clubs, gyms, spas, saunas, swimming pools, water centers, day centers, and children´s playrooms are closed, by order of the prime minister, including those operated by hotels and other accommodation providers.

The restriction does not apply to the provision of social and health care services including food aid, social welfare services, medical and rehabilitation services. UPDATE: 31.05.2021-people may be and move around in indoor public saunas, spas, swimming pools and water parks if  occupancy does not exceed 50%, the total number of participants is no higher than 200 people and no person is at said venues from 22:00 to 06:00.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

description:
14.03.2020 - Under the orders of Prime Minister Jüri Ratas (Center), the person in charge of the emergency situation currently in effect in Estonia, sports halls and clubs, gyms, pools, aqua centers, daycares and children's playrooms must all close immediately.
Hotels and accommodation establishments must also close their gyms, pools, saunas, and spas.
These restrictions do not apply to social service and healthcare service providers such as food aid, care services, medical treatments or rehabilitation services.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks.

description:
Estonia, March 27, 2020:
The National Government declares that catering establishments, including restaurants, cafés and bars, have to close at 10 pm for on-site consumption. After 10 pm, catering establishments may only open for the purpose of takeaway or home delivery services. Restrictions do not apply to employees of said establishments.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks.

description: The majority of shops will close and new movement restrictions will be introduced in Saaremaa and Muhu in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) Prime Minister Jüri Ratas announced late on Saturday night. On Saturday, Ratas (Center) signed an amendment which will see most of the stores and close contact service providers close their doors from Sunday (March 29) in the municipalities of Saaremaa and Muhu.Starting Sunday, March 29:Grocery stores, pharmacies, telecommunications stores, bank offices, parcel terminals, post offices, stores where technical aids and medical devices are sold or rented, and optician's stores may remain open in the municipalities of Saaremaa and Muhu.Construction stores may remain open for sales through a window or from the storeroom. The store's sales area must be closed.Gardening shops may also remain open.All other stores and markets must be closed to customers.All eateries must be closed for on-site eating, takeaway and delivery service for taking food home are allowed.All services that require close contact must be closed – cosmetic surgery services, beauty and personal services (for instance hairdressing, manicure, pedicure, beautician, tattooing and solarium services), and massage and other rehabilitation services as wellness services.Libraries are closed to visitors.The restriction does not include employees and owners, so e-commerce can continue.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Takeaway and Delivery only
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: The majority of shops will close and new movement restrictions will be introduced in Saaremaa and Muhu in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) Prime Minister Jüri Ratas announced late on Saturday night. On Saturday, Ratas (Center) signed an amendment which will see most of the stores and close contact service providers close their doors from Sunday (March 29) in the municipalities of Saaremaa and Muhu.Starting Sunday, March 29:Grocery stores, pharmacies, telecommunications stores, bank offices, parcel terminals, post offices, stores where technical aids and medical devices are sold or rented, and optician's stores may remain open in the municipalities of Saaremaa and Muhu.Construction stores may remain open for sales through a window or from the storeroom. The store's sales area must be closed.Gardening shops may also remain open.All other stores and markets must be closed to customers.All eateries must be closed for on-site eating, takeaway and delivery service for taking food home are allowed.All services that require close contact must be closed – cosmetic surgery services, beauty and personal services (for instance hairdressing, manicure, pedicure, beautician, tattooing and solarium services), and massage and other rehabilitation services as wellness services.Libraries are closed to visitors.The restriction does not include employees and owners, so e-commerce can continue.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: In order to prevent further spread of the virus, on April 1, the Estonian Ministry of Health established a rule on the availability of disinfectants in the trading floor or service room.  The order changes the requirement for the placement of disinfectant, which currently must be located at the entrance to a store or service hall.  From now on, the store owner can place it in the place where the disinfectant is most needed.  It is important that customers are clearly informed of where the disinfectant is located.  Otherwise, the customer must not enter the store.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 3, 2020, Estonia's government announces that from April 4, 2020 stores are required to calculate the maximum number of customers that fit in their premises while following the distancing requirements. Stores must monitor and limit store occupancy based on these calculations. Shops, post offices, pharmacies and service providers must also ensure that people waiting behind the door follow the rule and that there are no queues where people stand together more closely. According to the rule, stores should preferably be visited alone or in pairs, keeping a distance of at least 2 meters from other customers.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia, March 27, 2020:
The National Government declares that public sports halls, gyms, saunas, spas, sports clubs, swimming pools, water parks, day centres, casinos and slot machines halls, children’s playrooms, hookah cafés as well as recreation and entertainment facilities (including, for example, bowling, billiards, adult clubs) are to be closed. There are exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From May 2, 2020, outdoor gyms may open "provided the owner or possessor of the relevant outdoor gym ensures wet cleaning of the outdoor gym equipment at least once every 24 hours".
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 5 2020, Estonia's government announces that from May 5, 2020 driving schools are allowed to conduct driving lessons for drivers of motorised vehicles and cars, and transporters of dangerous goods, if they comply with the special requirements.Pursuant to the special requirements, only an instructor and a student without symptoms of the COVID-19 infection are allowed to participate in driving lessons. Disinfectants must be available in every vehicle. Organisers of driving lessons must clean all surfaces that a student touched after each lesson. Students and instructors may wear personal protective equipment of individual preference, for example, a protective mask or a visor.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers

description: On March 24 2020, Estonia's government announces that from March 27, 2020 Estonia closes all shopping centers and commercial establishments, with exceptions of grocery stores; pharmacies; stores where technical aids and medical devices are sold or rented on the basis of technical aid card or medical device card; bank offices; points of sale of telecommunications companies; parcel terminals; catering establishments where food is not consumed on site but only sold as takeaway; and post offices. UPDATE: From May 11, 2020, shopping centres and affiliated stores may open if the availability of disinfectants is ensured and customers are informed of the locations of disinfectants if not located at the sales area’s entrance or exit. Also, it is only allowed to be or walk around in shopping centres and affiliated stores in groups of one or two people while keeping at least two metres of distance from others.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia, March 27, 2020:
The National Government declares that catering establishments, including restaurants, cafés and bars, have to close at 10 pm for on-site consumption. After 10 pm, catering establishments may only open for the purpose of takeaway or home delivery services. Restrictions do not apply to employees of said establishments.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From May 18, 2020, there are additional provisions for catering establishments’ seating areas (such as that the availability of disinfectants to employees and customers is ensured).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

description:
Estonia, May 18, 2020:
The National Government declares that, in sales areas and in public rooms of shopping centres, it is allowed to walk around if the number of people in a group does not exceed 2, a distance of at least two metres with other persons is maintained and the availability of disinfectants to employees and customers is ensured at least at the entrance to and exit from the respective sales area. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks.

description:
Estonia, May 18, 2020:
The National Government declares that catering establishments have to close at 10 pm for on-site consumption as well as follow social distancing and hygiene rules. After 10 pm, catering establishments may only open for the purpose of takeaway or home delivery services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From May 28, 2020, this policy is extended indefinitely, making previous announcements about the complete lifting of restrictions for catering establishments (that is, previous End of Policy updates) obsolete.

description:
Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 – As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders. 
Saunas, spas, swimming pools, and water centres can open as of June 1. Compliance with the 2+2 rule, the requirement for dispersion of people, the requirement for 50 percent capacity, and the requirement for disinfection must be guaranteed according to the instructions of the Health Board. The rules on sports are applicable for swimming exercises. UPDATE: Starting from 11 March 2021, in Estonia the saunas, spas, pools, water parks and swimming facilities intended for public use must be closed until April 11, 2021.

description:
Estonia, May 18, 2020:
The National Government declares that, in sales areas and in public rooms of shopping centres, it is allowed to walk around if the number of people in a group does not exceed 2, a distance of at least two metres with other persons is maintained and the availability of disinfectants to employees and customers is ensured at least at the entrance to and exit from the respective sales area. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From June 19, 2020, keeping a safety distance of at least two metres, and a limit of 2 people in a group, is replaced by the rule that the scattering of people must be ensured.

description: 28. August 2020 - 0:00The police will also continue to restrict late-night alcohol sales in Tartu County.Vallo Koppel, Prefect of the South Prefecture, said that new students will arrive to Tartu for the new school year from very different areas (including from abroad), but since the epidemiological situation has worsened, we cannot ease the restriction on late-night alcohol sales in Tartumaa which was introduced on 7 August. Estonia, June 19, 2020:
The National Government declares that catering establishments have to close at 10 pm for on-site consumption as well as follow social distancing and hygiene rules. After 10 pm, catering establishments may only open for the purpose of takeaway or home delivery services.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From August 19, 2020, compliance with the disinfection requirements according to instructions from the Health Board must be ensured.

description: 28. August 2020 - 0:00As of tomorrow, 29. August, the police will restrict late-night alcohol sales in Harjumaa. By order of the head of the North prefecture, retail sale of alcoholic beverages will be restricted in Harju County from 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. The restriction will remain in force until further notice, but it is currently estimated to be a short-term restriction, the duration of which depends on the attitude and behaviour of people and their compliance with the requirement of dispersion. The Police and Border Guard Board and the Health Board will re-evaluate the relevance of the restriction once a week.“According to the Health Board, in Estonia, the risk for the spread of the infection is the highest in Tallinn due to large population and high population density. As of this morning, there are 61 active cases in Harju County, and the Health Board estimates that some of the infected persons contracted the virus directly or indirectly at an entertainment facility where it is common to consume alcoholic beverages.

description: On October 11 2020, Estonia's government announces that from October 11, 2020 citizens are encouraged to work remotely whenever possible. The Health Board is concerned over the virus spreading in workplaces. The agency emphasizes the importance of not going to work when ill, adding that getting better at home and only returning to work once healthy is in the interests of both the employee and employer.

description: On October 31 2020, Estonia's government that from November 2, 2020 the City of Tallinn is to switch from  to a so-called yellow scenario in terms of organization of work in the city's authorities for three weeks. The launching of the yellow scenario means that employees will use personal protective equipment and the employees whose work permits doing so will switch to working remotely. Employees remaining at workplaces will be dispersed. Meetings and training sessions will be held online if possible and the cleaning of workplaces will be enhanced.

description: On November 10 2020, Estonia's government announces recommendations to come into force on the 12th of November.   '• We recommend employees to work remotely if possible.  • Employers are advised to prepare a remote working plan and arrange remote working in case someone becomes infected with the coronavirus at work.  • We recommend cancelling all joint events, including Christmas parties, which are attended by people who do not come into contact on a daily basis. Celebrating Christmas with family is, of course, allowed.'

UPDATE: From November 16, 2020, up to 10 persons may be and move around together in catering establishments while keeping at least two metres of distance from others and it must be ensured that customers are not in the catering establishment’s sales or seating area from 12 to 6 am except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services.

description:
Estonia, August 19, 2020:
The National Government declares that, in sales areas and in public rooms of shopping centres, it is allowed to walk around if the scattering of people, the availability of disinfectants to employees and customers at least at the entrance to and exit from the respective sales area and compliance with the disinfection requirements according to instructions from the Health Board is ensured.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From November 16, 2020, the number of people in a group may not exceed 2.

description:
Estonia, September 25, 2020:
The National Government declares that, "[i]n the interests of ensuring public order, the right of retail sale of alcoholic beverages in a place of business where the retail sale of alcohol is permitted for consumption on the premises is suspended throughout the state from 00:00 to 10:00".
The policy is slated to end on October 24, 2020. UPDATE: From November 25, 2020, this policy is extended until January 26, 2021.

The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks.

description: From Dec. 28, 2020 stricter measures will be in place in Ida-Viru and Harju counties under the new directives, all catering must close, though restaurants may remain open for carryout services. UPDATE: Measures and restrictions necessary for preventing the spread of COVID-19” of 19 August 2020, additional temporary restrictions apply in Harju County and Ida-Viru County up to and including 31 January 2021.Given the above, this Order imposes uniform rules for catering establishments, entertainment facilities, public meetings and events as well as sports and hobby activities in all of Estonia.The opening hours of catering establishments and entertainment facilities and the relevant requirements for scattering are also aligned. According to the Order, instead of the former 25 people, including the instructor or trainer, from now on up to 50 people, including the instructor or trainer, are allowed to be in a group when engaging in sports outdoors.

target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries

description:
Estonia, January 18, 2021:
The National Government declares that, up to and including January 31, 2021, catering establishments in Ida-Viru County and Harju County may open if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed, business hours go from 06:00 to 19:00 and occupancy does not exceed 25%. From 19:00 to 06:00, people may be in catering establishment’s sales or seating area for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services only. There are exceptions to these policies.

description:
Estonia, September 25, 2020:
The National Government declares that, "[i]n the interests of ensuring public order, the right of retail sale of alcoholic beverages in a place of business where the retail sale of alcohol is permitted for consumption on the premises is suspended throughout the state from 00:00 to 10:00".
The policy is slated to end on October 24, 2020. UPDATE: This policy ended on January 26, 2021, as scheduled on November 18, 2020.

description:
In Harju county starting from February 1, 2021, the restrictions are maintained in shops, shopping centres, bank halls, postal offices, and other places. People must wear a mask indoors, movement must take place observing the 2 + 2 rule, the capacity of sales and service areas may be 50 per cent, the availability of disinfectants and adherence to the requirements of disinfection must be ensured. UPDATE: Estonia, March 11, 2021:
The National Government declares that sales areas of stores and public spaces of commercial establishments located indoors are to be closed. Goods may be sold and picked up outdoors if social distancing rules are followed. There are exceptions.
From May 3, 2021, customers may again be and move around in the sales area of stores and in public spaces of commercial establishments located indoors if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries

description:
Estonia, December 5, 2020:
The National Government declares that places where leisure services are provided may open if certain requirements are met (see [type_business_var]).
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From February 3, 2021, groups may only comprise up to 6 persons and leisure service providers already have to close by 9 PM.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia, December 5, 2020:
The National Government declares that catering establishments have to close from 10 pm to 6 am for on-site consumption as well as follow social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules. After 10 pm, catering establishments may only open for the purpose of takeaway or home delivery services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From February 3, 2021, groups may only comprise up to 6 persons and catering establishment's already have to close by 9 PM.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia. February 3, 2021. The current restrictions are maintained in shops, shopping centres, bank halls, postal offices, and other places. People must wear a mask indoors, movement must take place observing the 2 + 2 rule, the capacity of sales and service areas may be 50 per cent, the availability of disinfectants and adherence to the requirements of disinfection must be ensured. UPDATE: The sales areas of stores, except for stores selling essential goods, are closed
Starting from March 11, only stores selling essential goods may stay open, meaning grocery stores, pharmacies, stores selling aid equipment and medical devices, the sales points of the representations of telecommunications enterprises, optics stores, pet stores and filling stations. It is not allowed to offer catering on the premises of the filling station cafes.
The requirement of no more than 25% occupancy, the 2+2 rule and the obligation to wear a mask must be adhered to in the stores that may remain open, and in the public areas of shopping centres.
All other stores must remain closed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Starting from 3rd of February 2021, in Estonia government prohibited the sale of alcoholic drinks until 10 a.m. in the morning. UPDATE: In the interests of ensuring public order, the right of retail sale of alcoholic beverages in a place of business where the retail sale of alcohol is permitted for consumption on the premises is suspended throughout the state from 22:00 to 10:00. 
In force until:	31.05.2021

description:
Estonia, February 3, 2021:
The National Government declares that places where leisure services are provided may open if certain requirements are met (see [type_business_var]).
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From February 22, 2021, the 50 % limit on customer capacity only applies indoors. Now, the number of customers shall not be higher than 200 people indoors. Outdoors, the number of customers shall not be higher than 250 people and people are to be scattered.

The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From February 22, 2021, it must be ensured that the occupancy of catering establishment’s sales or seating area is no more than 50%.

Estonia, January 27, 2021:
The National Government declares that, "[i]n the interests of ensuring public order, the right of retail sale of alcoholic beverages in a place of business where the retail sale of alcohol is permitted for consumption on the premises is suspended throughout the state from 22:00 to 10:00".
The policy is slated to end on February 28, 2021. UPDATE: From March 1, 2021, this policy is extended until March 31, 2021.

description:
Estonia, December 5, 2020:
The National Government declares that customers may be and move around in indoor sales areas of stores, in service provider's service points and in public spaces of commercial establishments if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. There are exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From March 6, 2021, customers may be and move around in the sales area of stores and in public spaces of commercial establishments located indoors from Mondays to Fridays only. On Saturdays and Sundays, goods may be sold and picked up in outdoor sales or pickup areas of stores where scattering of people must be ensured.

description:
Estonia, March 6, 2021:
The National Government declares that, from Mondays to Fridays, catering establishments have to close from 18:00 to 06:00 for on-site consumption. During business hours, persons may also be and move around in outdoor service areas of catering establishments if the scattering of people is ensured. From Fridays at 18:00 to Mondays at 06:00, persons may be in catering establishment’s sales or seating and service area only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services. Catering establishments must also implement social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is slated to end on March 28, 2021.

The National Government declares that customers may be and move around in the sales area of stores and in public spaces of commercial establishments located indoors from Mondays to Fridays only. On Saturdays and Sundays, goods may be sold and picked up in outdoor sales or pickup areas of stores where scattering of people must be ensured. Social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules must be followed. There are exceptions.
The policy is slated to end on March 28, 2021. UPDATE: From March 11, 2021, sales areas of stores and public spaces of commercial establishments located indoors are to be closed. Goods may only be sold and picked up outdoors.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry),Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Estonia, March 11, 2021:
The National Government declares that grocery stores, pharmacies, stores where technical aids and medical devices are sold or rented on the basis of a technical aid card or medical device card, points of sale of telecommunications companies, optics stores, pet stores, petrol stations, or public spaces of commercial establishments and places of provision of services that are necessary for ensuring access to the aforementioned, may open if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. There are exceptions.
The policy is slated to end on April 11, 2021.

description: On March 9 2021, Estonia's government announces that from March 11, 2021 customers may be and move around in service providers’ service areas if compliance with the occupancy does not exceed 25%. The service provider shall ensure in its service areas the availability of disinfectants to employees and customers and compliance with the disinfection requirements according to instructions from the Health Board.

description:
Estonia, January 27, 2021:
The National Government declares that, "[i]n the interests of ensuring public order, the right of retail sale of alcoholic beverages in a place of business where the retail sale of alcohol is permitted for consumption on the premises is suspended throughout the state from 22:00 to 10:00".
The policy is slated to end on February 28, 2021. UPDATE: From April 1, 2021, this policy is extended until April 30, 2021.

description:
Estonia, March 11, 2021:
The National Government declares that catering establishments are to be closed except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is slated to end on April 11, 2021. UPDATE: From April 5, 2021, persons may be and move around in outdoor sales and service areas of catering establishments if the service provider ensures that its customers will not consume any food or beverages on the premises.

description: On April 22 2021, Estonia's government announces that from April 26, 2021 Students may be or move around in study buildings of general education schools, vocational educational institutions, institutions of professional higher education, and universities when general education students require educational support services or consultations for achieving learning outcomes, people are scattered in classrooms, and no more than two people move around together while keeping a distance of at least two meters from others, masks are worn, and compliance with the Health Board's disinfection requirements is ensured. These measures aren't applied in study buildings and other educational buildings when state-organized immunization or handling of blood is being carried out. The measures are to be in place up to and including 2nd May 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

The National Government declares that grocery stores, pharmacies, stores where technical aids and medical devices are sold or rented on the basis of a technical aid card or medical device card, points of sale of telecommunications companies, optics stores, pet stores, petrol stations, or public spaces of commercial establishments and places of provision of services that are necessary for ensuring access to the aforementioned, may open if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. There are exceptions.
The policy is slated to end on April 11, 2021. UPDATE: From April 26, 2021, this policy is extended until May 2, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Estonia, January 27, 2021:
The National Government declares that, "[i]n the interests of ensuring public order, the right of retail sale of alcoholic beverages in a place of business where the retail sale of alcohol is permitted for consumption on the premises is suspended throughout the state from 22:00 to 10:00".
The policy is slated to end on February 28, 2021. UPDATE: From May 1, 2021, this policy is extended until May 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Estonia, March 11, 2021:
The National Government declares that places where leisure services are provided may open if certain requirements are met (see [type_business_var]).
The policy is slated to end on April 11, 2021. UPDATE: From May 3, 2021, provision of entertainment services, all with or without designated seats, isn't allowed indoors.

description:
Estonia, April 5, 2021:
The National Government declares that catering establishments are to be closed except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. There are exceptions to these measures. Persons may also be and move around in outdoor sales and service areas of catering establishments if the service provider ensures that its customers will not consume any food or beverages on the premises.
The policy is slated to end on April 25, 2021. UPDATE: From May 3, 2021, customers may only be and move around in outdoor sales or service areas of catering establishments if the service provider ensures that the respective occupancy is no higher than 50%, the number of people is no higher than 10 people at a table and, from 21:00 to 06:00, people are and move around in said places only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Delivery and Takeaway Only,Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Estonia, May 3, 2021:
The National Government declares that indoor premises of catering establishments are to be closed except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. Persons may also be and move around in outdoor sales and service areas of catering establishments if the availability of disinfectants and compliance with the disinfection requirements according to instructions from the Health Board is ensured, the service provider ensures that the respective occupancy is no higher than 50%, the number of people is no higher than 10 people at a table and, from 21:00 to 06:00, people are and move around in said places only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is slated to end on May 9, 2021.
