description:
Estonia, May 3, 2021:
The National Government declares that indoor premises of catering establishments are to be closed except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. Persons may also be and move around in outdoor sales and service areas of catering establishments if the availability of disinfectants and compliance with the disinfection requirements according to instructions from the Health Board is ensured, the service provider ensures that the respective occupancy is no higher than 50%, the number of people is no higher than 10 people at a table and, from 21:00 to 06:00, people are and move around in said places only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is slated to end on May 9, 2021. UPDATE: From May 17, 2021, outdoor premises of catering establishments may be open for on-site consumption until 22:00. The availability of disinfectants and compliance with the disinfection requirements according to instructions from the Health Board shall now only be ensured indoors.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

description:
Estonia, May 24, 2021:
The National Government declares that catering establishments may open if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. From 22:00 to 06:00, people may be and move around in catering establishments only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From May 31, 2021, rules are simplified. Now, as before, catering establishments must ensure indoors and outdoors that the requirement of no more than 50% occupancy is met and no person is at catering establishment's sales or service area from 22:00 to 06:00, except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services. Indoors, "practising physical distancing" and wearing a mask is mandatory. Also, the availability of disinfectants and compliance with the disinfection requirements according to instructions from the Health Board shall still be ensured indoors.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On January 29 2021, Estonia's government announces that from February 3, 2021 a 50 per cent capacity requirement will be established for public meetings and events with stationary seating in the seating area and customers must be spread out when seated. The maximum number of people remains the same; the maximum number of participants in indoor events is 400. This includes public events, theater plays, movie screenings and conferences indoors with stationary seating. UPDATE: In Estonia, as of 11 March 2021, the public indoor spaces of all theatres, cinemas, museums, exhibition and conference facilities, children’s playrooms, bowling and pool halls, night clubs, casinos etc must be closed for visitors until April 11.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Republic of Estonia. February 3, 2021.Nationwide: It will be added to the restrictions that at the 50 per cent capacity, people must be spread out when seated. The previous limits are maintained, which means that in premises with stationary seating, the number of participants may be up to 400 and in premises without stationary seating, up to 250, considering the capacity requirement of the premises. For outdoor events, up to 500 people may participate as before. UPDATE: the original policy did not specify an end date, however, it ended on 22nd June 2021 with the easing of restrictions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
New movement restrictions will be introduced in Estonia in the Saaremaa and Muhu municipalities in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) and limit the burden on the health system. Stricter restrictions on movement will go into force on Monday March 30 2020.  A general 2+2 rule applies to moving around outside, according to which only 2 people can be in a public space together and a 2 metre distance must be kept from others.
If a person does not stick to the new measures the police will issue a warning. The next sanction used will be a penalty payment of up to €2,000.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: On April 3, 2020, Estonia's government announces that from April 4, 2020 stores are required to calculate the maximum number of customers that fit in their premises while following the distancing requirements. Stores must monitor and limit store occupancy based on these calculations. Shops, post offices, pharmacies and service providers must also ensure that people waiting behind the door follow the rule and that there are no queues where people stand together more closely. According to the rule, stores should preferably be visited alone or in pairs, keeping a distance of at least 2 meters from other customers.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 5 2020, Estonia's government announces that from May 5, 2020 driving schools are allowed to conduct driving lessons for drivers of motorised vehicles and cars, and transporters of dangerous goods, if they comply with the special requirements.Pursuant to the special requirements, only an instructor and a student without symptoms of the COVID-19 infection are allowed to participate in driving lessons. Disinfectants must be available in every vehicle. Organisers of driving lessons must clean all surfaces that a student touched after each lesson. Students and instructors may wear personal protective equipment of individual preference, for example, a protective mask or a visor.

description:
Estonia, May 11, 2020:
The National Government declares that shopping centres and affiliated stores may open if the availability of disinfectants is ensured and customers are informed of the locations of disinfectants if not located at the sales area’s entrance or exit. Also, it is only allowed to be or walk around in shopping centres and affiliated stores in groups of one or two people while keeping at least two metres of distance from others. Employees and owners/representatives of a shopping centre/store within a shopping centre are exempted from restrictions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks.

The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks.

description:
As of 17th May 2020, Estonia follows the 2+2 rule:
In public places and indoor premises, the so-called 2+2 rule remains in force, which means that both outdoors and indoors up to two people may be together, keeping a distance of 2-meters from other people. The rule does not apply to families or at homes. The rule applies to all activities in Estonia that do not take place in domestic conditions.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

When organising the exams the students must be dispersed in the exam room, the movement of groups of students must be dispersed

Estonia, May 18, 2020:
The National Government declares that catering establishments have to close at 10 pm for on-site consumption as well as follow social distancing and hygiene rules. After 10 pm, catering establishments may only open for the purpose of takeaway or home delivery services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. description:
June 1, 2020
Allow visitors into social welfare institutions, shelters, safe houses, and hospitals, provided that the head of a relevant institution guarantees that:
a set of instructions applies for these visits, compiled in cooperation with the Health Board
these instructions are followed, guaranteeing the use of personal protective equipment for employees, residents, and visitors, if necessary
the use of personal protective equipment is mandatory in social welfare institutions
these visits are organised in outdoor conditions or special rooms, if possible
visitors present a health declaration prior to the visit
disinfection requirements are met pursuant to the set of instructions

The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. description:
Estonia, May 18, 2020:
The National Government declares that, in sales areas and in public rooms of shopping centres, it is allowed to walk around if the number of people in a group does not exceed 2, a distance of at least two metres with other persons is maintained and the availability of disinfectants to employees and customers is ensured at least at the entrance to and exit from the respective sales area. The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. description:
As of 17th May 2020, Estonia follows the 2+2 rule:
In public places and indoor premises, the so-called 2+2 rule remains in force, which means that both outdoors and indoors up to two people may be together, keeping a distance of 2-meters from other people. The rule does not apply to families or at homes. The rule applies to all activities in Estonia that do not take place in domestic conditions. UPDATE: With effect from 19 June 2020, the Government of the Republic decided to replace the 2+2 rule with a requirement for people to disperse. This means that a safe distance between people must continue to be maintained, but the state no longer requires compliance with the 2+2 rule, as Estonian residents understand and accept the need to keep their distance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: With effect from 19 2020 June, the Government of the Republic decided to replace the 2+2 rule with a requirement for people to disperse. This means that a safe distance between people must continue to be maintained, but the state no longer requires compliance with the 2+2 rule, as Estonian residents understand and accept the need to keep their distance. The requirement will apply in public saunas, spas, swimming pools and water parks as well as bowling alleys, billiard rooms and children's playrooms. It will also apply in basic schools, upper secondary schools, vocational education institutions and higher education institutions, as well as in organising the activities of continuing education institutions, hobby schools and open youth centres. It will also extend to youth camps and student camps, sports activities and visits to museums and exhibitions.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Estonia, December 30, 2020.
By Government's order, in public indoor spaces, up to two persons may be and move around together while keeping at least two meters of distance from others.

description:
Estonia, January 18, 2021:
The National Government declares that, up to and including January 31, 2021, catering establishments in Ida-Viru County and Harju County may open if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed, business hours go from 06:00 to 19:00 and occupancy does not exceed 25%. From 19:00 to 06:00, people may be in catering establishment’s sales or seating area for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services only. There are exceptions to these policies.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries

description: In Ida-Viru county starting from 1st of February, the restrictions will be in shops, shopping centres, bank halls, postal offices, and other places. People must wear a mask indoors, movement must take place observing the 2 + 2 rule, the capacity of sales and service areas may be 50 per cent, the availability of disinfectants and adherence to the requirements of disinfection must be ensured.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Estonia, December 5, 2020:
The National Government declares that catering establishments have to close from 10 pm to 6 am for on-site consumption as well as follow social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules. After 10 pm, catering establishments may only open for the purpose of takeaway or home delivery services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From February 3, 2021, groups may only comprise up to 6 persons and catering establishment's already have to close by 9 PM.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia. February 3, 2021. The current restrictions are maintained in shops, shopping centres, bank halls, postal offices, and other places. People must wear a mask indoors, movement must take place observing the 2 + 2 rule, the capacity of sales and service areas may be 50 per cent, the availability of disinfectants and adherence to the requirements of disinfection must be ensured. UPDATE: The sales areas of stores, except for stores selling essential goods, are closed
Starting from March 11, only stores selling essential goods may stay open, meaning grocery stores, pharmacies, stores selling aid equipment and medical devices, the sales points of the representations of telecommunications enterprises, optics stores, pet stores and filling stations. It is not allowed to offer catering on the premises of the filling station cafes.
The requirement of no more than 25% occupancy, the 2+2 rule and the obligation to wear a mask must be adhered to in the stores that may remain open, and in the public areas of shopping centres.
All other stores must remain closed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Shopping Centers
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia, February 3, 2021:
The National Government declares that places where leisure services are provided may open if certain requirements are met (see [type_business_var]).
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From February 22, 2021, the 50 % limit on customer capacity only applies indoors. Now, the number of customers shall not be higher than 200 people indoors. Outdoors, the number of customers shall not be higher than 250 people and people are to be scattered.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Commercial Businesses

After 21:00, catering establishments may only open for the purpose of takeaway or home delivery services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks.

description:
Estonia, 22.02.2021.
The Government's order requires employees and visitors of social welfare institutions (general\special care homes) to wear a mask as personal protective equipment inside and on the territory of the relevant institution. The penalty payment is 9600 euros.
The policy is slated to end on 28.02.2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: In Estonia, from 28 November 2020 until 4 December 2020, In public indoor spaces, people are required to wear a protective mask to cover their mouth and nose. This includes special care homes, where all visitors and employees are required to wear a mask. UPDATE: The policy was set to last until February 21, 2021, it has been extended to February 28, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia, February 22, 2021:
The National Government declares that catering establishments have to close from 21:00 to 06:00 for on-site consumption as well as follow social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules. After 21:00, catering establishments may only open for the purpose of takeaway or home delivery services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From March 3, 2021, business hours for on-site consumption may go from 06:00 to 18:00.

description:
Estonia, March 3, 2021:
The National Government declares that catering establishments have to close from 18:00 to 06:00 for on-site consumption as well as follow social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules. After 18:00, catering establishments may only open for the purpose of takeaway or home delivery services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is slated to end on March 28, 2021. UPDATE: From March 6, 2021, persons may be in catering establishments’ sales or seating and service area only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services from Friday at 18:00 to Monday at 06:00.

description:
Estonia, December 5, 2020:
The National Government declares that customers may be and move around in indoor sales areas of stores, in service provider's service points and in public spaces of commercial establishments if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. There are exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From March 6, 2021, customers may be and move around in the sales area of stores and in public spaces of commercial establishments located indoors from Mondays to Fridays only. On Saturdays and Sundays, goods may be sold and picked up in outdoor sales or pickup areas of stores where scattering of people must be ensured.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Estonia, March 6, 2021:
The National Government declares that, from Mondays to Fridays, catering establishments have to close from 18:00 to 06:00 for on-site consumption. During business hours, persons may also be and move around in outdoor service areas of catering establishments if the scattering of people is ensured. From Fridays at 18:00 to Mondays at 06:00, persons may be in catering establishment’s sales or seating and service area only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services. Catering establishments must also implement social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is slated to end on March 28, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, 03.09.2021.
U.S. Embassy in Estonia declared masks or mouth/nose coverings are mandatory in all public indoor places. Exceptions are children up to age 12, and those with medical conditions as long as the 2+2 rule is observed.  
Failure to comply with restrictions can result in fines up to 9,600 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all indoor spaces
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia, March 6, 2021:
The National Government declares that, from Mondays to Fridays, catering establishments have to close from 18:00 to 06:00 for on-site consumption. During business hours, persons may also be and move around in outdoor service areas of catering establishments if the scattering of people is ensured. From Fridays at 18:00 to Mondays at 06:00, persons may be in catering establishment’s sales or seating and service area only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services. Catering establishments must also implement social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is slated to end on March 28, 2021. UPDATE: From March 11, 2021, catering establishments have to close except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants

description: Starting from 11 March 2021, in Estonia students in grades 1 to 4 are not allowed to be in the school buildings anymore either, and those preparing for the basic school final exams and state exams will not be allowed to have contact learning. It is still foreseen that in emergency cases, primary school students may continue to spend time in school buildings and participate in activities organised there. Children with special educational needs and institutions managing them can remain open in a limited and safe capacity.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting from 11 March 2021, in Estonia students in grades 1 to 4 are not allowed to be in the school buildings anymore either, and those preparing for the basic school final exams and state exams will not be allowed to have contact learning. It is still foreseen that in emergency cases, primary school students may continue to spend time in school buildings and participate in activities organised there. Children with special educational needs and institutions managing them can remain open in a limited and safe capacity. UPDATE: From 17 May 2021, in Estonia contact learning will be allowed for all students of general education schools, vocational schools, universities of applied sciences, and higher education institutions. The general health protection requirements and the instructions and recommendations of the Ministry of Education and Research must be taken into account when organising studies. Indoors, care must be taken to ensure air quality through ventilation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Estonia, April 5, 2021:
The National Government declares that catering establishments are to be closed except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. There are exceptions to these measures. Persons may also be and move around in outdoor sales and service areas of catering establishments if the service provider ensures that its customers will not consume any food or beverages on the premises.
The policy is slated to end on April 25, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants

description: In Estonia, from 28 November 2020 until 4 December 2020, In public indoor spaces, people are required to wear a protective mask to cover their mouth and nose. This includes special care homes, where all visitors and employees are required to wear a mask. UPDATE: The policy was set to last until April 04, 2021, it has been extended to April 25, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 22 2021, Estonia's government announces that from April 26, 2021 Students may be or move around in study buildings of general education schools, vocational educational institutions, institutions of professional higher education, and universities when general education students require educational support services or consultations for achieving learning outcomes, people are scattered in classrooms, and no more than two people move around together while keeping a distance of at least two meters from others, masks are worn, and compliance with the Health Board's disinfection requirements is ensured. These measures aren't applied in study buildings and other educational buildings when state-organized immunization or handling of blood is being carried out. The measures are to be in place up to and including 2nd May 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia, April 5, 2021:
The National Government declares that catering establishments are to be closed except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. There are exceptions to these measures. Persons may also be and move around in outdoor sales and service areas of catering establishments if the service provider ensures that its customers will not consume any food or beverages on the premises.
The policy is slated to end on April 25, 2021. UPDATE: From May 3, 2021, customers may only be and move around in outdoor sales or service areas of catering establishments if the service provider ensures that the respective occupancy is no higher than 50%, the number of people is no higher than 10 people at a table and, from 21:00 to 06:00, people are and move around in said places only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, April 5, 2021:
The National Government declares that catering establishments are to be closed except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. There are exceptions to these measures. Persons may also be and move around in outdoor sales and service areas of catering establishments if the service provider ensures that its customers will not consume any food or beverages on the premises.
The policy is slated to end on April 25, 2021. UPDATE: From May 3, 2021, customers may only be and move around in outdoor sales or service areas of catering establishments if the service provider ensures that the respective occupancy is no higher than 50%, the number of people is no higher than 10 people at a table and, from 21:00 to 06:00, people are and move around in said places only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services.

description:
Estonia, March 11, 2021:
The National Government declares that grocery stores, pharmacies, stores where technical aids and medical devices are sold or rented on the basis of a technical aid card or medical device card, points of sale of telecommunications companies, optics stores, pet stores, petrol stations, or public spaces of commercial establishments and places of provision of services that are necessary for ensuring access to the aforementioned, may open if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. There are exceptions.
The policy is slated to end on April 11, 2021. UPDATE: This specific policy was repealed on May 3, 2021 (the respective section was removed from the order).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia, March 11, 2021:
The National Government declares that sales areas of stores and public spaces of commercial establishments located indoors are to be closed. Goods may be sold and picked up outdoors if social distancing rules are followed. There are exceptions.
The policy is slated to end on April 11, 2021. UPDATE: From May 3, 2021, customers may again be and move around in the sales area of stores and in public spaces of commercial establishments located indoors if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed.

description:
Estonia, May 3, 2021:
The National Government declares that indoor premises of catering establishments are to be closed except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. Persons may also be and move around in outdoor sales and service areas of catering establishments if the availability of disinfectants and compliance with the disinfection requirements according to instructions from the Health Board is ensured, the service provider ensures that the respective occupancy is no higher than 50%, the number of people is no higher than 10 people at a table and, from 21:00 to 06:00, people are and move around in said places only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is slated to end on May 9, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, May 3, 2021:
The National Government declares that indoor premises of catering establishments are to be closed except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. Persons may also be and move around in outdoor sales and service areas of catering establishments if the availability of disinfectants and compliance with the disinfection requirements according to instructions from the Health Board is ensured, the service provider ensures that the respective occupancy is no higher than 50%, the number of people is no higher than 10 people at a table and, from 21:00 to 06:00, people are and move around in said places only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is slated to end on May 9, 2021. UPDATE: From May 17, 2021, outdoor premises of catering establishments may be open for on-site consumption until 22:00. The availability of disinfectants and compliance with the disinfection requirements according to instructions from the Health Board shall now only be ensured indoors.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From May 31, 2021, there is no longer a group limit of 2 people in public indoor spaces, a rule change which also affects leisure service providers.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Estonia, May 24, 2021:
The National Government declares that catering establishments may open if social distancing, face covering and hygiene rules are followed. From 22:00 to 06:00, people may be and move around in catering establishments only for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services. There are exceptions to these measures.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From May 31, 2021, rules are simplified. Now, as before, catering establishments must ensure indoors and outdoors that the requirement of no more than 50% occupancy is met and no person is at catering establishment's sales or service area from 22:00 to 06:00, except for the purpose of takeaway or provision of delivery or transport services. Indoors, "practising physical distancing" and wearing a mask is mandatory. Also, the availability of disinfectants and compliance with the disinfection requirements according to instructions from the Health Board shall still be ensured indoors.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

Estonia, June 23, 2021:
The National Government declares that catering establishments may open if social distancing and hygiene rules are followed. The rule of "practising physical distancing" in indoor spaces does not apply to families and in cases when such requirements cannot be reasonably ensured.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From August 9, 2021, it must be ensured that the total number of customers is no higher than 50 people in catering establishments.
